reviewText:
First of all i played this game with keyboard and it was very painful,just DON'T play the game with a keyboard,Only 8 directions to shoot can be a total b*tch on some bosses and makes it even more frustratingly difficult (bosses are hard by themselves.).

Gameplay

I liked the simplicity of it,roll and shoot.The problem is,there is no real 'motivation' to make you try 43th time to try kill X boss. Yes,you get its soul but does it affect anything? Sadly no,you get literally nothing out of this.

I also did not enjoy wandering a empty world that has nothing much interesting in it,they just act as a way between bosses.

Story

I think the makers did a good job on story,though i felt like adding some more 'clear' lore to it would be great.You just fight a titan that you know nothing about and be done with it.

Atmosphere

I really enjoyed the Titan Souls' atmosphere. The music,the graphics were very nice. I think the atmosphere part is the strongest part of the game. But still,the world feels a bit dead.

Difficulty

Yes,the game is very difficult,you get hit one time,and you are dead. Difficulty is more about dying to a boss and trying to memorize its pattern,with some luck in it.

Replayability

The game has a bunch of unlocked game modes after you beat it,but i didn't feel like playing the game again after finishing it.


Overall

This game is not a bad game but rather feels kind of incomplete. You should buy it if it is really in a good discount,you like difficult games and uncovering hidden story,otherwise you should STAY AWAY from it.

reviewText:
NOTE: This is a GOOD game, but with one very big flaw.

Unpopular opinion maybe, but I can't deal with the poor retry system, which in a game like this is kind of a REALLY BIG DEAL. I will change this to a thumbs up review if they update the game so that you can instant retry a boss or retry starting from a point very near the boss door.

This is a game where the bosses are intentionally very difficult, where you die if you get hit only once, so you die CONSTANTLY and REPEATEDLY and OFTEN, but every time you die, you have to walk ALL THE WAY BACK TO THE BOSS CHAMBER. At first you dont mind. The bosses are challenging and exciting and they are really great quality fights.

But in a game where the player is EXPECTED to die many many times, I do not understand the purpose of making the player tediously walk all the way back to the point of retry again, and again, and again. It's such a small thing, but it really is kind of a big deal. It's like playing Super Meat Boy, but every time you die, you get kicked back out to the main menu. Would SMB still be a great game if that were true? That's kind of the situation we're dealing with here.

I will change to recommended INSTANTLY as soon as retries are no longer a pain.

reviewText:
I love the art, the style, the simple mechanics, fantastic stuff.  Except, the game is... not fun.

I love challenging games, games that are merciless, cruel, and whip you.  It makes victory that much more satisfying and rewarding.

Titan souls?  No, it isn't challenging.  It wears the APPEARANCE of challenge.  The bosses are basically 90% luck 10% skill.  Everytime I beat a titan, save for the first couple, it doesn't feel satisfying.  It just feels like you got lucky.  After a dozen tries, this time the arrow was 'drawn just enough' and the angle was 'just enough' for the game to recognize it as on target.

The trick to the titans is obvious, so you don't feel smart for figuring it out.  Getting to the titans is frustratingly slow.  Firing your arrow is frustratingly slow.  Getting your arrow back is frustratingly slow.  Dying and getting another crack at a Titan is frustrating slow.

The game and the mechanics are identical from start to finish.  So traversing the big and open world, while pretty and with a nice atmosphere, gets very boring, very quickly.  I was pretty pumped to get this game, but after about 10 titans in, i'm done, it's got nothing left to offer.

Don't waste your time, just replay Shadow of the Colossus on PS2.
voteText: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There's lovely world here and great potential for a fully fledged epic title but in its current state I cannot wholeheartedly recommend this game. Yes the world is beautiful and elegant which fits with the minimalistic gameplay style that defines the experience. That said this game demands the most from you without it giving you the most back. There are many design flaws with this title that produce counter intuitive logic. It's not fulfilling to die for reasoning you presume to be consistent with the games logic only to find that you entirely wasted your time. You will often try mistaken ideas that seem logically possible but aren't, whilst the game does nothing to steer you away from that kind of reasoning.

Anyone who has played this game without a guide knows exactly what I'm talking about from the illogical arrow does damage when returning (yet not to you?!) to often illogical boss weakness which turn out to be nothing but aesthetic choices rather than gameplay dynamics. The game records your death count and when you combine that with the inconsistent design there's a real dilution of the sense of achievement there could be here when you finally kill a Titan. A feeling you may feel like jumping  for joy in achievement but reflecting back it often feels out of sheer luck that you got your arrow off than any kind of skill.

Technically this game optimization is very poor It struggles immensely with alt tab not to mention the games clueless ability to understand resolution formats getting them often entirely wrong. I've also had game crashes and artifacting from alt tabbing in which the prior screens elements are left behind. This with an options menu that is overall very lacking which would be more acceptable if the standard price wasn't so high at 11£.

Overall this is a cool game just not a good one but I really hope they take what they have here expand it and tighten up all of its potentially great aspects. Right now it feels like an unrewarding and often empty relationship, to which the netgain of the experience feels one of loss in terms of your time especially when there are superior titles out there like the Shadow of the Colossus. For now watching the game is far more enjoyable than playing it to its underwhelming conclusion, lets hope in the future the next title can rectify that.

reviewText:
This game looks beautiful, has simple mechanics with the potential to be very deep, a nice (totally barren) overworld, and a fantastic soundtrack with some excellent boss tunes. It's too bad you only hear about 2-10 seconds of any particular boss song.

Despite everything it has going for it, and how much I wanted to love this game, I simply cannot recommend it.

The first four boss fights got me so excited for the rest of the game. Excellent, 95% skill-based boss battles? What's not to love? It soon became apparent that the game was turning itself into an exercise in tedium. Boss arenas got further and further away from the checkpoints. Bosses killed you without warning in a matter of seconds. It takes about 15-20 seconds of walking per death to reach a boss room. I expect the average total death count for a first playthrough to be somewhere around 150-200 times. That's a lot of unnecessary backtracking.

At first glance, and maybe about an hour into the game, it can easily be likened to something like Dark Souls or Shadow of the Colossus. In practice, however, it ends up playing more like I Wanna Be The Guy. The amount of split-second coordination doesn't reward a quick wit and clever decision-making; it grants death. You die, you die again, and continue dying until you get a lucky shot and come out on top. It doesn't feel satisfying to win against a boss knowing that you haven't really gotten any better at the game. It feels cheap.

Titan Souls set out to be an exciting adventure, and it has all the trappings of one. The most apt word I could use to describe this game is this:

Disappointing.

reviewText:
More like Toilet Souls hurr hurr I'm gonna print this out and put it on my fridge /s

The difficulty is rather decieving, as most of the game's bosses can be killed within 5-30 seconds if you figure them out (which isn't that hard), even if you don't have a guide. It's EXTREMELY tedious, all thanks to how much walking you have to do. The game world is way too large and is the sole reason why my experience was padded out to about 2 hours. As other reviewers have noted as well, until the end of the game, all of the checkpoints spawn you a good distance away from your enemy, forcing you to walk all the way to the boss room every time you want to retry.

There's no real reward for progressing or even beating the game, either. All you really get are three modes that just make the game more difficult/frustrating/unfun, and for beating the final boss, some text is translated, like boss intro blurbs. Nope, there's no unlockable bosses, weapons, locations, nothing. Yay..?

There's no real replay value either. As previously stated, the three modes you get for beating the game only make the game harder and more frustrating. Like a no-roll run, a hard mode that screws with previously successful strategies, and a mode that only gives you one life that uses the hard mode changes. Considering you die in one hit and some of the bosses can be EXTREMELY cheap (changing their patterns on a whim, bad hitboxes, etc), you can already see where that'd go.

There's barely any story other than what's on the store page for the game, and a very short and vague dialogue sequence that many players won't even see (which locks them out of the final boss). Hell, the entire game is extremely vague and gives you barely any reason to care about trudging onward. At least in a story-starved game like The Binding of Isaac, the genesis Sonic games, or the first Hotline Miami, the fun of the gameplay keeps you going. Here, you're given next to no direction and a Gainax Ending that really doesn't tie up anything or explain anything.

The music is okay, but it's mostly generic fantasy tunes similar to what you've probably heard a million times before in other fantasy titles, such as those from Bioware or Bethesda. Personally, most of it does give me a pleasant Neverwinter Nights vibe. The art direction is also alright, but some of the monsters seem lazily designed or just look out of place. Some other parts of the game look rather low-effort as well, such as a river in the hub area.

This is definitely a sale game, and not worth the $14.99. It's easily beatable in about 2 hours, and there's really no reason to come back to it. By the time you beat it, you're already burnt out, frustrated, unsatisfied, and wishing it was something better. For $14.99, this is wasted potential. If it were like $4.99 or something, then it'd definitely be worth a buy.

reviewText:
In short, this game lacks soul.

Why am I killing these monsters? Am I evil? Are these things evil? Is this just some sport? I don't know.

The game gives no context to any of my actions. There is no exposition to explain what all of this is. There are no changes to the world whenever a monster is killed. There are no powers gain from killing these monsters directly or indirectly. It doesn't even build my character: the same boring unskippable cutscene plays every time I defeat a monster. Maybe when I defeat the monster with the heart, I should gain my own heart, but no, I just gain this white goo and rays shoot out of my stomach. Maybe I don't want rays to shoot out of my stomach.

Why, when I die, do I have to do walk through the same path again? Because the environment never changes, this is just a repetitive action. The lack of context to having to walk back means I don't feel remorse, but frustration at the game. Why do I respawn sometimes on an elevator on the switch so it moves me back to the previous zone? What the hell, game?

The highlight of the game is the mechanics of the monster fights. Each one of them has a trick, which when you figure it out, you can defeat them quickly. But, it is marred by having to walk back to the monster room each time you die with one hit. That time not fighting bosses is time wasted.

If this game is about just boss fights, make it about boss fights. Put everything in a menu. There's no reason why half my time should be spent staring at the same background art.

reviewText:
FIrst and foremost, if you don't have a controller or gamepad you can use with your computer, absolutely don't buy this. There are parts that are almost impossible to do with just a keyboard.

What about the actual game? Well, if you like having absolutely no difficulty curve, this is your game. You need to be able to pick up the mechanics fast in order to have any fun, otherwise you'll be constanly dying almost immediately, since basically any attack that hits will instantly kill you. And while dying might not be much of an annoyance at first, the longer you go on the more the game ends up being 40% loading screens, 45% transit between the respawn point to the boss room, 12% actually fighting the boss, 1% exploration, and 2% watching the boss smash your corpse over and over to add insult to injury.

As far as the gameplay goes, you play as a puny weak little human with a bow and a single arrow that you can force pull towards you after it is fired. You use these to fight various bosses in rooms of various layouts and sizes reflecting the residing boss, and must use its attack pattern and your environtment to either get past the boss's defenses or hit its weakspot. This can be accomplished by directly firing your arrow at your enemy or by hitting it while you draw your fired arrow towards you. It's similar to being a top-down 2D Shadow of the Colossus, except all of the Colossi are the annoying, smaller, fast colossi, now with multiple methods of attack and where you simply have to observe their behavior for a few lives to figure out what to do. The primary challenge is simply in properly executing your plan without being slaughtered within seconds of activating the boss, which is very, very hard.

All in all, I wouldn't mind the game so much if you respawned in the boss room, cutting out one of the loading times and all the time you spend in transit, and if it was optimized more for use with a keyboard and not just a controller. If it wasn't for those issues I feel I could really enjoy the game.

If you REALLY like boss runs with no change in gear, no skills or special attacks, no rewards for defeating said bosses, then this game may be for you.  Sadly, not my taste :c

reviewText:
Before you buy this game, be warned: it's nothing but boss battles.

I can't say I didn't spend a lot of this game really enjoying myself. It has interesting visuals, lovely music, and it was a delight trying to work out the puzzles behind the bosses, but when I say 'it's nothing but boss battles,' I mean that.

The world feels lifeless. There's some artistic symbolism that someone may be tempted to call a story, but there are no characters, no motivation, no development, no choices. I consider it a missed opportunity. Lots of effort was put into making the world pretty and interesting, but nothing even hints at the motivations of whatever it is that put all these things here for you to interact with. There is also no arc either. When you first land in the game you're doing exactly the same stuff that you're doing in the middle and at the end of the game.

Even Super Mario Bros. had more emotional engagement than this. At least it had an understandable goal to go along with its pretty visuals and artistic landscape. In this game you're given an arrow and you have the opportunity to murder everything in sight, if you want, and that's pretty much the extent of it. You murder eighteen things and you're done. You don't get an ending.

Let me repeat that. This game doesn't have an ending. You see a defeat animation of the final boss, hear some wooshy sound effects, and then the credits roll.

Normally I'd be fine with a game that wants to be pure and have no story at all. I don't have any similar complaints about Tetris or Solitaire, but this game is different. It teases the player with unfulfilled hints at a story that isn't there.

As for the gameplay itself, I found that I very much enjoyed the difficulty level, but the biggest complaint I had was the punishment for failure. You have to stroll back to the boss chamber from the nearest save point, and then rejoin the battle, at which point absolutely nothing has changed.

When you resume combat with the boss, you're back in the exact same battle with exactly the same number of hits remaining (one), and with the exact same number of hits remaining for the enemy (one), so effectively there is no punishment at all for dying except for having to take a tedious walk, sometimes up to fifteen seconds. The game could have spawned you just outside the door, but it doesn't, and often, you spend way more time walking back to the arena than you do actually fighting the boss.

And just as there is no penalty for dying, there's no reward for winning, except that you get to see a short animation. It's the same animation every time, except for the final boss, which is slightly grander, but has an identical theme. That's the animation I mentioned before that plays before the credit roll.

If you do choose to buy this game, I hope that this helps you. Don't get invested in the lovely world and interesting circumstances. Don't assume you will get a narrative payoff for all the hard work you invest into beating all the bosses. You'll be disappointed if you do.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this, and I appreciate a challenge, but it just isn't what I was hoping for.

Clearly the Souls series and Shadow of the Colossus are big influences here. This is what drew me to the game in the first place. Titan Souls falls short of it's inspirations though, and it's mostly down to the pacing, and the perspective.

Pacing first; it's pretty bad. You're just going room to room, fighting boss after boss. The boss-only thing can work well, it was stunning in SotC. There's no exploration here though, no motivation even (why am I doing this?), no build-up... The game feels very flat as a result, compartmentalized and hard to lose yourself in. A big deal, I think.

Okay, onto perspective. I don't mean in this in a 2d/3d or top-down/over-the-shoulder sense. Just that in SotC and Dark Souls, there are staggeringly large things to fight, but these games first show a world that is scaled to suit you. The awe/horror/wonder comes from encountering something that exists outside of your frame of reference. In Titan Souls, these giant" boses take up as much screen real estate as you would expect the player character to. They appear to exist in stasis til you approach them; they're just... there. Sat in their sterile
hoursPlayed: no backstory implied. Maybe if the boses were more interesting

reviewText:
Fun bits of gameplay in between tons of slow walking through an empty world.  The world isn't the real problem though, it's the respawning after dying (and it happens a lot).
The game would be greatly improved by respawning you right outside the boss room like Hyper Light Drifter.  It doesn't do that though, you have to fade in, re-walk 5-45 seconds to the boss room, watch the bosses intro, and then try to not die in 2 seconds (you die in 1 hit in this game).  The gameplay and bosses are actually fun too, which makes it all the more annoying that the game is ruined . . .

What I would personally change:
-Respawn right outside the boss door where you died (or let the player pitch a tent where they wanna respawn)
-Gradually increase your run speed with continual running (or just blink into speed run after a time like Okami)

This game would literally be fun to me with just those small changes.  Right now though, it just isn't a fun experience.

I could not recomend this game for anyone without a controller and if you do own one I also cannot recomend this game at full price.

reviewText:
The game is just about Boss battles. That's it. I'd have liked some mobs in between just to get the hang of the controls. Or better still, mobs that mimic the Boss's powers and weaknesses before each battle would have helped to get an idea of how to combat each boss.

As it stands, just expect to die about every 30 seconds as you walk into a room, get murdered, and have no idea what to do until 50 deaths or until you give up and look at a guide.

To summarize, this game is challenging, but rewarding. However, the fact this game refuses to do anything to assist the player in learning the game is a major turn off for me. It's a Grinder's grinder and that's just not my style.

reviewText:
Cripplingly difficult indie boss rush game with shadow of the collosus vibes.
----

+ Graphics are pleasant.
+ Soundtrack is great.
+ Good atmosphere.

- It's soooo damn hard.

----

If you're into difficult games, you'll like this. You play as a guy with a bow and one arrow which magically returns to you and you have to face off against a ton of consistantly difficult bosses. They die in one hit to their weak point, but you die in one hit from almost everything.

When you die, there is usually an annoying run back to the boss room that wastes a ton of your time. Often the run back to the boss takes longer than you spend on the actual attempt at killing the boss.

The game has a great soundtrack and interesting visuals which combine to give it some pretty decent atmosphere, but it is just too damn hard for me to enjoy.

reviewText:
This is one of those masochist games. You shoot a single arrow from a bow, and you can't shoot again until you get the same arrow back. You can hold the shoot button after you fired the arrow and it will slowly move back toward you. If an enemy hits you, you die instantly and go back to a checkpoint. Everything is designed just to make it a pain in the rear to play. They could've done a few other things to make it even more of a chore, like making it so when you press left you go right, and when you press down, you go up, etc., but the developer hit the nail on the head for misery, so no need to step it up any further.

Aside from the annoying one arrow situation, you can roll, you can shoot an arrow, and you can run a bit. You walk into a room, a large monster attacks you, and you try to kill it before it hits you one time and you have to do the whole thing over. I'm fairly certain that's the whole game. Rooms spaced apart which you can pick from, each containing a different monster that wants to one-hit-kill you.

The good news is that with Steam refunds, you should know if you cannot stand this game within about 5 to 10 minutes of starting. If playing games with 90s-looking graphics that are designed just to be difficult and little else, then Titan Souls might just be for you! Unfortunately, I'd need to be paid wages just to play this game any longer. At least I get paid to be bored or annoyed at work.

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Few words about the game
No map, no clear directions where to go... All you have is one magical arrow, personal experience you're gaining through dozens of deaths and will to beat those titans. Playing Titan Souls will put your mind into an endless torture and torment... except that's gonna last about 3 hours and will be fun :D Add 3/4 of Shadow of the Colossus, mix it with 1/4 of Dark Souls, sprinkle it with 16-bit graphics and tadaaa, Titan Souls!

Advantages
Gorgeous art style everywhere, bosses and surroundings are beautifully modeled, damn I'm falling in love with that kind of art style too quickly >_<
Truly amazing, beautiful and moody music that's still playing in my headphones, along with great sounds of steps, smashes, rain, lightnings, shooting arrows, rain, RAIN ._.

reviewText:
Fast bosses, one-hit death, and no chance to observe beforehand mean most battles are over in a few seconds until you've died and retried enough to learn the enemies' attack patterns.  Many bosses also have a puzzle element that will take even more retries to solve.

I like a good challenge, and I think I would love this game...except after every death you have to trudge back from the save point.  In the two hubs I encountered, there were stairs leading from the save point up to a fork, then more stairs to the various bosses — and stairs slow running speed and prevent rolling.

This game could so easily have been straight awesome challenge.  Instead you spend more time getting back to the boss than actually fighting it.  Imagine a 15-second countdown every time you get hit.  That's not difficulty, just tedium.

reviewText:
This game isn't bad, but it leaves much to be desired.

If you're into atmospheric games with intense fights, you might want to pick this game up when it's on a big sale. Playing through it is decently enjoyable. The fights are diffcult and intense, and figuring out how to beat each boss feels like a small puzzle. The art style looks very nice and the music and controls (if played with a gamepad) are decent as well.

That said, the game has serious issues. The one-hit-death mechanic makes the fights intense, but taking up to a minute to walk to the boss again after you've really becomes tedious after you've done so a million times. Some fights are also extremely anti-climactic in the opposite way, where you kill the boss in under 5 seconds. All in all the fights aren't very satisfying.

Recommend only if you thoroughly enjoy the genre and it's on sale.

reviewText:
This game is ludicrously hard, to the point where it's not even funny at times, or fun for that matter. Now I can't really fault the game for being too hard, I'm sure my lack of skill is partly to blame. Even so, this game will take a lot out of you.

Let's start with my only real substational complaint: The respawn times. While I understand that the game is meant to be thought-provocing and atmospheric, every time you die, you have to wait a second or so before the screen fades to black, and then another few seconds before the screen fade in again, now at your last checkpoint. This might not sound like much, but the battles are incredibly fast-paced and intense, and you can only take one single hit before dying. This means that respawning REALLY breaks up the gameplay, and often. Perhaps the long wait was meant as a punishment for dying, but it made me mad at the game rather than myself, even if I did fault myself for my death. You can assume that .4 of my 4.4 hours were spend waiting for the game to let me play again.

So! Now that that one complaint is out of the way, let's praise the game a bit, shall we? The Titans are diverse, and while defeating each one can take many, many frustrating tries, doing so is quite rewarding in the end. The game looks gorgeous, a real treat for any pixelart lover. The music is also fantastic, doing a great job of setting a more calming mood outside of battle, and having a varied library of Titan Themes. That's what I'm calling them.

Now, I'll be frank and say I only got through the game all the way to the true final boss out of sheer unwillingness to let this relentlessly difficult piece of virtual entertainment beat me, and near the end I was mostly incredibly frustrated, but as I've said before, this was at least partly due to my own ineptitude. But in the end, it felt incredibly rewarding. The true final boss will likely stick with me for months to come.

Titan Souls offers a challenge. A real challenge, one that doesn't last too long, but it'll feel like a terrible eternity. And when you finally beat it, you'll be glad you did. Just be prepared to get very, very angry.

reviewText: Tiresome. The concept of a 1 hit kill game could be really awesome but I found myself feeling tired and cheated rather than invigorated and callenged, and this is coming from someone whose favourite game is dark souls. The gameplay consists of boss after boss, with little to nothing inbetween except pretty landscapes, all of which can 1 hit you with any of their billion hurtboxes all of which guard their hitbox which you must hit at least 3 times. I really wanted to like this game because you can see the love that's been poured into it, but after multiple attempts I've resolved to deleting it from my library; officially giving up. All round this game was a saddening and frustrating experience. The graphics are alright though, somewhat clunky in parts but all over an interesting feel. It just felt like difficulty" was favoured over gameplay. If the bosses were 1 hit kills too then maybe I could make it through

reviewText: I like hard games. I even love hard games. But I cannot tolerate hard games that punish your failure with time. Titan Souls is an otherwise lovably hard game in which you spend more time getting back to where you were before you died than you spend playing the actual game. That's bad.\n\nIt takes upwards of 30 seconds to get to a boss that can kill you in an instant. I have no problem with instant death, but the ratio is a little skewed. If you respawned right in front of the boss door this game would be recommended, but I can't even summon the patience to play it.

reviewText:
This game is amazing! To the developers my hat goes off to you!

Dark Souls meets Shadow of the Colossus meets Zelda: A Link To The Past


Played the game for quite a bit of time, and couldn't find myself ever getting bored. The visuals and the music keep everything interesting, even the parts where you wander the world looking for your next boss.


The gameplay is challenging and boss fights are amazing.  You need to be quick to react, yet it's not to fast that you get stuck or have unfair deaths. Your deaths are a result of you not planning your path, or mislciking.

All in all this game for me is a definite 9/10. It brings back memories of old school gaming, with a new school feel. Can't wait to go deeper into this world and see what other bosses lie ahead!

Cons:
Personally there may be some.... but so far, with the amount i have played, I have found none

reviewText: What could have been a fun game was ruined by the some baffling design decisions.  The game is basically a boss rush which is fine, but for some reason it  loves to waste your time by having you run to the bosses each and every time you die. There is no reason for this. There are no puzzles to be solved or enemies to be beaten, you just respawn at a point and have to walk to the boss again. It doesn't sound that bad, but trust me: Having to run to a boss, even if it just takes 10 seconds, feels like a huge chore after you died ten times to a boss. I do not understand why the game doesn't give you the option to simply respawn in front of the boss chamber.

reviewText:
Seems to be the 2-D counterpart to Shadow of the Colossus. Now I haven't played SotC, but I thought I would try this game out since it looked interesting! OMG I was right.This game is simply amazing.

The game starts with you waking up in a large unkown area and your job is to go around and defeat a bunch of different and challenging bosses, just like SotC.
The game is a heavy trial and error genre, since you have to keep replaying bosses to find their weak spot. The bosses only die in one hit but so do you. This in turn makes it incredibely satisfying when you finally defeat a boss.

One problem I had with the game was that it was really difficult to find your way around in the beginning. I get that the game incurres exploration, but I just found the map a little too huge. It didn't take long before I got tired of this and then I decided to follow a guide to find my way around and it was so much better. It is recommended to try to kill the bosses without a guide though, since it kinda kills the point of the game, but feel free to use a guide for exploring

In conclusion the game is really great and immensely satisfying to complete, but before of the difficulty. The navigation problem nowhere near makes the game bad

In this game all you fight are boss.  The best way too think of it is this,   zelda but only boss and one weapon.  The weapon is a spear that you can throw then pull back too you. This game is vary hard and you die a lot.  It is very satisfying to finally kill a boss but what ruined the game for me was the walk back to the boss. The walk back means you can't get right back in the action.   Outer games where you die a lot like super meat boy or hotline miami understand that fast respawns are very important.

cons

reviewText: I see a lot of bad reviews for this game that make NO sense, what-so-ever. If you read them please consider one thing: This game was made for a generally masochistic audience. These people have never played games of this genre, this genre is pseudo-masochistic RPG... like dark souls, salt and sanctuary, etc... Some of them actually had the balls to complain about dying in 5 seconds yet spending 20 seconds running to the boss, HAHAHA, I guess they never played shadow of the colossus(a game that had clear influence over this one). The game doesn't pat you on the back for finding the keyboard. In the hour time or so that I've played and explored the game, I beat the first 4 bosses and was amazed at the size of the game, thereafter. From the reviews I was expecting it to be a short and sad experience, but I guess they never managed to kill the first bosses because the areas become VERY large and amazing afterwards. The game is very simple. You die in one hit, but you also kill in one hit. The trick is you have to hit bosses at a very specific time. I've only stumbled onto bosses, and I haven't had any sort of alteration with levels, gear, or weapons. But I also haven't seen any alteration to difficulty, which was pleasing, since health doesn't seem to go up. Every boss is equally as hard depending on how skilled you are with timing. This game rewards you for having a quick reaction time, and the ability to spot extraordinary yet sensical details(weaknesses). You are only given a few seconds with a boss at a time to get a grasp of his movement and attack animations before you die, so if you're the type of person who is rather squeamish as 90% of these reviewers seem to be, then perhaps check out youtube instructions on when to attack. This will make your gameplay a lot more enjoyable. Or you could go the route the developers intended and simply spend a little extra time dying to figure out a strategy for you. P.S. The cube boss on the first level has an achievement for being killed by running into his eye with your arrow arched back ;) Hope you enjoy this massive boss-hunter as much as I did!

reviewText:
Short Version: Before you buy this game, try out the free demo if it's still available. If you like it and want more, go for it. Just be warned that the rest of the game is a dozen more bosses and about 10 minutes of map exploration. Strongly recommend you get this on sale.

Long Version: This is a pretty short, but challenging game. You're basically just walking around a fairly small world map until you find a checkpoint, and from there you'll find 2-3 boss rooms in the immediate area. 16 main bosses total, plus 1 hidden boss (your reward for exploring the full map and finding a single hidden path) and the final boss on Hard Mode

The boss fights are a good challenge. Each boss is unique, and they feel more like a puzzle than an endurance challenge. If you can avoid a bosses attacks long enough to discover it's only weakness, you are then tasked with figuring out how to exploit the weakness. Once you figure out a strategy, it's only a matter of executing it perfectly. Most the bosses only take one hit to kill, but getting that hit in is an excercise in gamepad finesse. So you might fight a boss 20 times, but when you do finally kill it, it'll be in the first 5 seconds of battle.

I beat the game in just over 2 hours. Beating it unlocks 3 more levels of difficulty: Hard Mode (faster bosses, harder tactics), Iron Mode (no death run), and No Run No Roll Mode (sheah right, as if). I'll try Hard Mode, but likely I'll put the game down permanently before I finish it.

I would only recommend this game if it's on sale. I paid $4 for it and feel like that was a good price. If I paid full price I would be pretty annoyed at how short this game is and how little content there is. Aside from the bosses (which are definitely well done and this games only real selling point), there is only a single puzzle that you use your bow & arrow for - and it's the sort of challenge you get in the very first puzzle room in a Zelda game. There's really no story to speak of at all. There's a few lines of dialogue, but it doesn't have any context, so it's kind of dumb and pointless. The developers could have done a lot more with the map (there's a good number of designs and mysterious carvings here and there: why not some text to help build a story?).

Cons:

reviewText:
I personally enjoyed the game but it definitely as some downsides. For this particular game, I feel as a pros vs cons list is the most effective way to know if it will be enjoyable for you.

Pros:

-Awesome OST
-Great world design and graphics
-Simplistic controls that makes it easier to get into the game
-Unique concept of 1 hit 1 kill
-Lack of details makes it all the more intrguing
-High difficulty

Cons:

-Lack of details gives lack of motivation
-High difficulty
-You have to walk back to the boss when you inevitably die
-There's nothing to do between bosses. The game is similar to Shadow of The Colossus but, in shadow, there were still things to do like killing salamanders
-No reward system
-Not worth $15 but is worth buying when on sale

In my opinion, the goods outweigh the bads but, obviously, not everyone will share this viewpoint which is why I recommend the demo to test the waters a bit.

reviewText:
Imagine a beautiful top-down boss-only combination of Dark Souls and Shadow of the Colossus. Great, right? Oh, but you have 1 hitpoint.

The visuals and music create a fantastic atmosphere, which is a huge shame given the excessively rigid gameplay design.

I remember when the original 'Ludum Dare' version came out awhile back and I played it. Even though it was just as difficult, it was a small demo that showed a lot of potential. Unfortunately, they didn't move from their original design whatsoever and therefore you die in one hit against every single boss, and then have to trek your way back to the boss. Every. Single. Time. They give you a few checkpoints, but what does it matter if it still results in spending more time getting to the bosses than you do fighting them?

More specifically, the real problem is there is very little sense of progression. In Dark Souls (for example), even though it technically takes longer to reach the bosses than it does to fight them, there's significant opportunities for progression. You can explore the area for loot, shortcuts, and characters; you can learn how to best avoid or confront the obstacles along the way; and perhaps most importantly, you can take time to study AND appreciate the boss fight most of the time without fear of dying in a few seconds. Not to mention, you can change your loadout for the fight however you desire. I'm not saying that Titan Souls needs all these things of course. But it simply has very little progression and the bosses are very aggressive and fast. You keep flinging yourself against them until you get that perfect shot, without really any change to speak of other than hoping that your reflexes and accuracy are what the fight is demanding.

I noticed a very questionable design choice...the character runs by holding A, but there's no reason to ever want to walk. Every single boss has relatively quick movements and running is a strictly better alternative, especially since you get killed in one hit. Having the option to roll is nice, but they should have made running" the default movement. Now I'll admit that I purposely have been avoiding spoilers but out of the 10 or so bosses that I fought
date: I didn't see any moment where walking proved useful. Without a stamina bar of some kind (which would make the current game even more difficult)
recommended: having to hold down a button to move faster feels like a needless formality.\n\nThe animation that happens when you kill a boss is exactly the same every time
hoursPlayed: and unskippable unless you exit the game. And what are their souls giving me exactly? Certainly not more health
voteText: speed
helpfulPercent: or power. So
votesHelpful: then why so much fanfare with the animation?\n\nI do applaud the developers for at least offering a demo
votesTotal: something a lot of developers nowadays sadly neglect. Even so
votesFunny: after the demo I bought it somehow hoping for a more wholesome experience
commentsCount: so temper your expectations.\n\nIf you mostly like the art and music (which again
column16: are great)
column17: I really recommend just watching a speedrun or let's play instead of buying this."

Dodge bosses attacks during that timeframe waiting for the quarter second window when their weak point is exposed.
Audio and graphics are alright, but the story is overly minimalistic even after it expands in new game+.
A super difficult game. Not difficult in a way that makes you think What a thrilling challenge that was!"

reviewText:
So I just finished the game and wanted to share this review with you. Please take your time reading this and let me explain under what conditions I recommend this game.
First things first:

-This game has a splendid soundtrack for most of the time. As music is a very personal point at least I can say (as being a musician myself) that the music fits to the overall atmosphere of the game.

-The graphics are beautiful compared to other top down games from this century (such as hero siege, relic hunters zero, hotline miami 2, etc.)

Now lets get to the gameplay. I played it with the keyboard and had no complains about the controls. I wont describe how the mechanics are in detail but rather point out the results out of them.

-It feels smooth to run around the world and shoot and so on

-Depending on what boss you are on it feels more or less lucky to kill one. For some bosses i was disappointed that it worked, for others it felt just great and satisfying

-You learn the tactic of each boss by dying to them several times before even discovering their weakness. This can be annoying as for some bosses it takes too many deaths or more likely too much time. This phase of the bossfight is the most disputable one in my opinion for as you know how to kill a boss the fight immediately depends only on your reaction and skill to bring it down and the game starts to get what it was ment for: fighting bosses and kill them (not discovering how to do that)

-The respawn time is fair and the way to the boss is short enough

-The overworld is relatively big but its the perfect size. You are completely alone in this world except for the titans. Hence an encounter makes the titan feel exalted and mighty and the main character just small and weak. This is a brilliant effect just reached by games like Shadow Of The Colossus" and makes this big world worth exploring and the games atmosphere so magically

-There is no real story in this game. This is a huge minus because you are willing to know why you are killing these titans and what is going on in general. At least there is some text appearing as you walk through the game that gives you the idea of what is happening but it is just too little to get this satisfying feeling of a progressing story. But this game does not rely on a story to thrive in atmosphere because the "not knowing" what is going on underlines the unsettling encounters with each titan

-The Titans themselve are well crafted. Each has its own mechanic and the developers were pretty creative in making them all different

-The game is really short with its 19 bosses

These are my impressions of Titan Souls. I would like to conclude by saying that this game is worth a try and is developed properly. BUT in relation to its length it is not worth its price at all! I bought in on sale and so should you do unless you are a complete fanboy of top-down-2d-pixel-graphics-boss-fight-games.
An adequate price in my opinion would be 7€/$.
Thanks for reading and excuse my bad english."
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What is Titan Souls? A try to recreate the feel of 'Shadow of the Colossus' and 'Dark Souls' fused together into one, 2-dimensional package. Sadly, it takes out the main ingredient of those 2 games: Fun. This game isn't fun, it's a chore. You know what to do, the bosses all have 1, very obvious weak-point, but it's very difficult to hit that singular point. You know why? Because playing with a keyboard makes this game absolutely unplayable. Yes, the developers recommend a controller, but I don't want to buy third-party hardware just to finish this game. That would be a waste of money, since finishing this game would be a waste of time. Anyways, back to the gameplay: The bosses are frustratingly hard, and since they serve as a tutorial, my motivation to finish this game has vanished extremely fast.

What else is there besides the broken, barebones bossrush? A generic, boring, ugly and empty overworld to explore. Great.

The game looks okay, nothing special.

The music is okay as well. Too generic for my tastes, tries too hard to be epic.

Thank god I actually didn't waste my money on this, since it was a gift, but I still feel angry. So much missed potential.

reviewText:
While this game gives strong nods to a number of other titles and genres--harnessing the weight of Shadow of the Colossus, the feel (and name) of Dark Souls, and plenty of others, I'm sure--it holds its own, delivering an approximation of a story, but leaving room for discovering the story of the world you are exploring, and how you fit into it.

It is a little frustrating at times, but there is a certain sense of accomplishment unmatched in most games.

Definitely a strong showing, and well worth the time and effort. Just make sure to kill all the titans, as design is the strongest aspect of the game, and I'd hate for you to miss out.

reviewText:
As a shameless fanboy for all things Dark Souls related, this title doubtless accomplished its job when I couldn't resist checking it out. As the title implies, it borrows heavily from Fromsoft's Souls series, but with a much more minimal aesthetic, and a shifted emphasis from combat to brainteasing. It scratched that masochistic itch well enough, but only for a shockingly brief 3 hours, and during that short time I encountered some problems greater than difficulty.

Titan Souls focuses exclusively on the rush of victory following a particularly difficult boss; the entire game is composed only of wide open quiet stretches between bosses that will test your resolve to perservere. They have one critical weakness, exposed for desperately short moments, which one must first identify before striking. So when my wild shot between frantic dodges finally connected, it took my breath away without fail.

That said, it was quite a trial of patience to reach victory, and some foes fell on the wrong side of unreasonable. I confess, I had to look up the weakness to one, and to this day I'm still not entirely sure how I beat the final boss. So, Titan Souls is worth the price, barely, but only if you already own the controller that is impossible to play without.

reviewText: I've played the hell out of the demo version. The full product disappoints. Why? It's bare bones. Titan Souls is a pretty, retro looking boss-rush type of a game. Your character has one weapon (a bow) and dies from one hit. The task is to fight and win with all 19 boss creatures. Most of them require from You to find and plant your arrow in their... weak spot. It's fun, but those simple mechanics get boring very quickly. There's no real reward for winning, no leveling, no new abilities. Bosses look great, but figuring them out takes a minute or two. Then starts the frantic battle to hit there weak spot, often resulting in chance, not skill. With no real progression or reward, Titan Souls loses it's charm. I couldnt get myself to play that game. It tries to be a 2D version of Dark Souls in it's vague storytelling (or rather non-existing storytelling) and high, unforgiving difficulty. In the end, it's a failure. Pretty looking, good sounding (really spot on OST, by the way), but nevertheless - unappealing.

reviewText:
The game takes its inspiration primarily from Shadow of the Colossus and Dark Souls; I personally believe they're great games. Mechanically, The largest influce those two titles have had on Tital Souls is 1) the level of difficulty and 2) the boss-fight based style of SotC.

Now, within the original games these aspects are used near flawlessly; however Titan Souls become stuck largely because of it's scope.
The reason Dark Soul's diffulty and challenge works so well as a gameplay point is that due to the complexity of the game and variety of things to do eventually overcoming the challenges it throws at you is rewarding. Killing the first boss, or even first few enemies in that game is satisfying as it demonstates the players ability to learn and master the many systems the game incorperates. Titan Souls meanwhile offers little satisfaction is this regard as it is incredibly mechanically simplistic; you can walk, roll dash, fire a single arrow and have to retrive it in order to attack again; the use of all this isn't hard to grasp, you'll have done so before encountering the first enemy. To get a solid grip on Dark Soul's mechanics might take the better part of hours of gameplay. That's where the fun lies. Titan Souls offers a challenge in a similar elk to DS, but in such a condensed manner that it can feel like a repetative slog, as opposed to a bountiful system of intricate trials.

Meanwhile, for Shadow of the Colossus, the game does boil down to largely consisting of just sixteen bosses, but it's everything that truly makes the game; the sprawling map to explore, along with the visual feast of it's unique graphics style. But, back in Titan Souls, the world offers little in the way of exploration outside of the bosses, with the map serving as a overworld map, linking the individual boss rooms together. And as for the graphics (and yes, they do have a certain charm) are not too dissimilar to the art style of numerous other games; leaving the world, in part, uninteresting to explore and venture into.

As a final point, I know how little I've played, but I've given it a go and seen the game and personally, it's just not for me. It has taken cues from some fantastic games that I hold in high regard, taken their essence, stripped it back into something so simplistic and acute the fun was left out.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about this game, the ideas behind it are good, and it does have good intentions. However, I've come out of the game feeling more frusterated than like I completed a fun, hard challenge. The art design is pretty pleasing to the eye,  the controls are nice and tight, and the music is pretty good.
Titan Souls is a glorified one hit KO boss rush dressed up as a retro Shadow of the Colossus without any real feelings of progression. There is nothing else to do besides slaying Titans, and that's a real shame. There were many opportunities to hide nice secrets in the overworld, but since what it does have (murals) adds nothing to the combat or the game in general, it ends up being more disappointing.
Lorewise, it feels like a mess. It tries to be as vague as possible, and when you do find murals depicting what could be lore, it is meaningless and doesn't add anything to the game. There was a large mural in the Forest area that no matter how I looked at it, it meant absolutely nothing. There was no context.
As I've stated before, the overworld is empty. SotC made up for the large overworld by adding upgrades to health and stamina, but since Titan Souls has no health mechanic whatsoever, and the bosses are one hit KOs anyway, there is no point to the overworld except as acting as a hub between the actual game. So the more time I spent on the overworld, the more I got bored of it.
Most of the bosses operate on a Think Fast!" attack system. Where the boss will attack at ludicrous speed without giving any tell worthwhile. The amount of times I started the boss fight
date: only to get killed a second afterwards because I had no clue where the boss was landing an attack is too much. The game gets most of the difficulty from this. And while some bosses have a rest in between a combo
recommended: the rest is not longer than 1-2 seconds long. So anticipating the direction of the boss to how long you need to pull the arrow back and avoiding death at the same time
hoursPlayed: creates even more frusteration. It gives off an RNG/luck feeling

reviewText:
Well, I read the negative reviews. I expected a game that was entirely too short, too frustrating, and too unpolished to be worth its asking price of $15. So, I dutifully waited until the game went on sale for under $5, and went in with low expectations.

The result? I was surprised. Titan Souls is a pleasure to play. At its core is the exploration of a simple concept: what if the terrifying big bosses were just as fragile as you? Both you and your foe will die after one decent hit, although landing this one decent hit can be quite a challenge.

You have at your disposal a single, magical arrow that can be alternately shot, then retrieved by magically attracting it to the player. You can also run and roll to dodge enemy attacks. Both shooting and retrieving the arrow force you to stand still, and the arrow will fly further the longer you hold down the attack key. Titans also tend to be very quick and very aggressive, so even finding the time to get a shot in can be very difficult.

The Titans themselves are beautiful (and often quite clever) in their design. As I mentioned, the weak point of each Titan tends to be evident, but it often takes some thinking to force the Titan to expose its weakness. Sometimes just seeing its weak point can be challenging, as often Titans will kill the uninitiated player in a matter of seconds after commencing battle. But when everything comes together, that moment, when your arrow hits your opponent square in the weak point it was guarding so effectively, is indescribable!

The world is also beautiful, but a little dull. Titan Souls' greatest weakness is the delay between fighting Titans, in which the player watches his corpse be pounded by the last Titan, then respawn several seconds walk away from where the fight took place. Generally there was a delay of 10-20 seconds between losing a fight and challenging the Titan for a rematch.

I often found that I didn't really mind, certainly not as much as other reviewers. Titan Souls is packaged so beautifully, with lush 2.5-3D pixel art and a gorgeous soundtrack. However, the purpose of these trimmings is clearly just to accentuate the stellar gameplay. In an industry obsessed with making games more like movies, it's a breath of fresh air!
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The best way to describe this game, it's a 2D Shadow of the Colossus. You have a bow with 1 arrow that you must retrieve after every shot. They die with one shot of your arrow, but you need time your shot. Wait for a pattern and when they finally open up you probably have a second to react. Not for the impatient to say the least as you will die over and over again.

reviewText:
People say this game is frustrating, which at times, can be true.
However, I absolutley LOVE the challenge, and anyone else who loves a good challenge will love this game.
It is not a game that you should look up how to beat, the fun comes from figuring out the weakness of each boss.
For some bosses, it's straightforward, and others it takes a few (or many) deaths to figure it out.
Fighting the same boss over and over may prove troublesome for some, but I loved getting a little closer each time, and when you finally hit that sweet spot, you totally feel like a badass titan slayer. This game gives roughly 4 hours of playtime, and more if you want to playthrough hard mode, but the real fun in this game comes from the first playthrough because if you know how, you can cheese pretty much all of the bosses. Pick up this game, its worth the play, but don't give in and look at a guide.
Also, might I add, the soundtrack is AMAZING and the art is BEAUTIFUL.
One more thing. You NEED a controller.

reviewText:
Contrary to people that bash the game for what it is, i think its beautiful. The visuals and soundtrack design are outstanding, however, the game is not without its flaws, ALAS, big ones:


1- The camera: The camera will be fine for most of the game, UNLESS you fight against someone in a big arena, in that case the camera ALWAYS moves way too much and you might end up out of camera (happened to me several times). Its a real shame that this can be fixed so easily but it hinders your skills so much, even if its for under 5 seconds, those 5 seconds are easily the difference between win or defeat

2- Rolling: In this game there are 2 buttons, both wich serve 2 functions when hold or just pressed. The movement one has the feature of making you able to run when you hold it, and when you press it you do a quick roll. The problem comes from the fact that speed is key in this game and you want to be running as much as possible. This however, places the spotlight into the problem that whenever you want to run, your character will first do a roll, wich is a long quick movement that you CANNOT stop nor change the direction of. Ive been killed way too many times because my character would roll into obvious danger instead of moving where i wanted him to go. Maybe this could have been a 3rd button.

3- Keyboards: DO NOT -I REPEAT- DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME WITH A KEYBOARD. You use the movement controls to aim with your arrow, with an analog joystick that means you aim wherever you please, with a keyboard this means you are locked to 8 directions. This doesn't look like a big problem except for a few bunch of bosses, but still, one of those is the final boss, and its very obvious that if you, like me, played this with only a keyboard, you would have a better time playing with a joystick.




Other than that, this game is beautiful, might not be worth 15 dollars tho, as you can finish it in 4-5 hours, but i bought it on a 75% discount and i enjoyed this way better than my 200 hours at MGS V: TPP.

reviewText: Titan Souls is a RPG that has one and only one rule. The rule of ones. You have one life, take one it and your dead. Each boss had a weakpoint, hit it, they are dead. You only have one arrow that you shoot from your bow and call back to you. This game is only about this concept, two fighting as equals. The entire game is fighting up to 18 entirely unqiue bosses, aka titans. Each one has there own concepts and weak points. Now, you will die, a lot. There is a lot of back tracking which is the main complaint people have with this game. I found it fine as it wasn't a long walking distance to the boss. The soundtrack is great and the pixel art is astonishing. I enjoy this game greatly. To add to challenge, 3 extra challenge modes plus 1 reveal mode add more content to the game. 8/10

reviewText:
Well, I read the negative reviews. I expected a game that was entirely too short, too frustrating, and too unpolished to be worth its asking price of $15. So, I dutifully waited until the game went on sale for under $5, and went in with low expectations.

The result? I was surprised. Titan Souls is a pleasure to play. At its core is the exploration of a simple concept: what if the terrifying big bosses were just as fragile as you? Both you and your foe will die after one decent hit, although landing this one decent hit can be quite a challenge.

You have at your disposal a single, magical arrow that can be alternately shot, then retrieved by magically attracting it to the player. You can also run and roll to dodge enemy attacks. Both shooting and retrieving the arrow force you to stand still, and the arrow will fly further the longer you hold down the attack key. Titans also tend to be very quick and very aggressive, so even finding the time to get a shot in can be very difficult.

The Titans themselves are beautiful (and often quite clever) in their design. As I mentioned, the weak point of each Titan tends to be evident, but it often takes some thinking to force the Titan to expose its weakness. Sometimes just seeing its weak point can be challenging, as often Titans will kill the uninitiated player in a matter of seconds after commencing battle. But when everything comes together, that moment, when your arrow hits your opponent square in the weak point it was guarding so effectively, is indescribable!

The world is also beautiful, but a little dull. Titan Souls' greatest weakness is the delay between fighting Titans, in which the player watches his corpse be pounded by the last Titan, then respawn several seconds walk away from where the fight took place. Generally there was a delay of 10-20 seconds between losing a fight and challenging the Titan for a rematch.

I often found that I didn't really mind, certainly not as much as other reviewers. Titan Souls is packaged so beautifully, with lush 2.5-3D pixel art and a gorgeous soundtrack. However, the purpose of these trimmings is clearly just to accentuate the stellar gameplay. In an industry obsessed with making games more like movies, it's a breath of fresh air!

reviewText: The best way to describe this game, it's a 2D Shadow of the Colossus. You have a bow with 1 arrow that you must retrieve after every shot. They die with one shot of your arrow, but you need time your shot. Wait for a pattern and when they finally open up you probably have a second to react. Not for the impatient to say the least as you will die over and over again.

reviewText:
Short review: This game is incredibly fun, although sometimes frustratingly difficult. Get it for a great challenge.

If you are a fan of tense, fast-paced fights and single life-single kill mechanics, you'll enjoy this game.  The soundtrack is amazing, the world design is fantastic, and the bosses each feel great and unique.  That's all I really have to say, I loved this game through and through, and the extra achievements give each boss some replayability.  The background world has plenty of lore and world-building, even for a pixel-graphics game, and the story pretty is interesting once you can unlock the text.

For anyone put off by the negative reviews, most of those people haven't even beat the game.

Don't believe them, each boss has its own mechanics and system.  You kill them all the same, because of course you do. You only have one bow and one magical arrow the entire game, which necessitates killing everything the same way.  But the ways in which you reveal a bosses weak point or have to excute the correct timing vary with each fight, and the game is anything but stagnant.  The game is a bit short on bosses, but unless you're a mechanical genius it'll take you several dozen deaths to clear them all, and then even more if you try a harder second playthrough.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A simple and beautiful game. You have a bow, one arrow... and a butt-load of titans to destroy. To call this an adventure game is... kinda right. While the only real gameplay is found in the 20-ish boss fights, the space between their arenas is lovingly crafted, pixelated goodness; accompanied by just the right kind of soundtrack.

I won't discuss the bosses in great detail, but to say that there's a lot... and I think I missed some. Difficulty varies, but each fight will require you to map out their behavior, test a method, fail and try again... and again. Over the short play time required I died 199 times... and I think that was good going.

I would thoroughly recommend the title, and as it's 75% off for the next 4 hours... get on it quick![8.2]

reviewText:
The game takes its inspiration primarily from Shadow of the Colossus and Dark Souls; I personally believe they're great games. Mechanically, The largest influce those two titles have had on Tital Souls is 1) the level of difficulty and 2) the boss-fight based style of SotC.

Now, within the original games these aspects are used near flawlessly; however Titan Souls become stuck largely because of it's scope.
The reason Dark Soul's diffulty and challenge works so well as a gameplay point is that due to the complexity of the game and variety of things to do eventually overcoming the challenges it throws at you is rewarding. Killing the first boss, or even first few enemies in that game is satisfying as it demonstates the players ability to learn and master the many systems the game incorperates. Titan Souls meanwhile offers little satisfaction is this regard as it is incredibly mechanically simplistic; you can walk, roll dash, fire a single arrow and have to retrive it in order to attack again; the use of all this isn't hard to grasp, you'll have done so before encountering the first enemy. To get a solid grip on Dark Soul's mechanics might take the better part of hours of gameplay. That's where the fun lies. Titan Souls offers a challenge in a similar elk to DS, but in such a condensed manner that it can feel like a repetative slog, as opposed to a bountiful system of intricate trials.

Meanwhile, for Shadow of the Colossus, the game does boil down to largely consisting of just sixteen bosses, but it's everything that truly makes the game; the sprawling map to explore, along with the visual feast of it's unique graphics style. But, back in Titan Souls, the world offers little in the way of exploration outside of the bosses, with the map serving as a overworld map, linking the individual boss rooms together. And as for the graphics (and yes, they do have a certain charm) are not too dissimilar to the art style of numerous other games; leaving the world, in part, uninteresting to explore and venture into.

As a final point, I know how little I've played, but I've given it a go and seen the game and personally, it's just not for me. It has taken cues from some fantastic games that I hold in high regard, taken their essence, stripped it back into something so simplistic and acute the fun was left out.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about this game, the ideas behind it are good, and it does have good intentions. However, I've come out of the game feeling more frusterated than like I completed a fun, hard challenge. The art design is pretty pleasing to the eye,  the controls are nice and tight, and the music is pretty good.
Titan Souls is a glorified one hit KO boss rush dressed up as a retro Shadow of the Colossus without any real feelings of progression. There is nothing else to do besides slaying Titans, and that's a real shame. There were many opportunities to hide nice secrets in the overworld, but since what it does have (murals) adds nothing to the combat or the game in general, it ends up being more disappointing.
Lorewise, it feels like a mess. It tries to be as vague as possible, and when you do find murals depicting what could be lore, it is meaningless and doesn't add anything to the game. There was a large mural in the Forest area that no matter how I looked at it, it meant absolutely nothing. There was no context.
As I've stated before, the overworld is empty. SotC made up for the large overworld by adding upgrades to health and stamina, but since Titan Souls has no health mechanic whatsoever, and the bosses are one hit KOs anyway, there is no point to the overworld except as acting as a hub between the actual game. So the more time I spent on the overworld, the more I got bored of it.
Most of the bosses operate on a Think Fast!" attack system. Where the boss will attack at ludicrous speed without giving any tell worthwhile. The amount of times I started the boss fight
date: only to get killed a second afterwards because I had no clue where the boss was landing an attack is too much. The game gets most of the difficulty from this. And while some bosses have a rest in between a combo
recommended: the rest is not longer than 1-2 seconds long. So anticipating the direction of the boss to how long you need to pull the arrow back and avoiding death at the same time
hoursPlayed: creates even more frusteration. It gives off an RNG/luck feeling

reviewText: I want to tell myself that I love this game, I try to tell myself that I love this game...but sadly and recluctantly, I have to admit, I don't! Hat's of to the developer, the concept of the game is exactly want I've wanted in a game since I fist picked up a controller all those years ago. But for me, this game is to much style over substance! The difficulty is way to steep, and this is coming from a guy who regulary plays the classics! (megaman/battletoads ect, ect) And whilst I get the whole minimulist theme, I just don't think it works well in this format. My biggest gripe with the game, is'nt the fact that you will DIE, DIE and then DIE some more. It's the fact that when you do DIE, you have to travel back to your murder scence and this takes time and effort and after your 3rd or 4th trek, it all becomes a total drag! No matter how expansive and mystical the landscape appears, on your 5th journey through the same area, you just start losing a connection with the game. It's a real shame Titan Souls is'nt designed better as it really could have been a Titan.

reviewText:
Great. Another game that thinks Bulshit is Difficulty.
Let me explain:
Everything is a 1HKO. that itself isnt a bad thing, but
The game's Movement and Firing is like Castlevainia's: Solid, Fast Movement, but slow, clunky firing. This would be fine... If the game was properly desined around it. And, for two of the first four bosses, it is!
The Slime and Golem are both designed greatly to produce both challange and fun.
Too bad the other two wernt.
The Frozon Brain Bube is Challanging, but not in the fun way. When you shoot it, It starts to move... AND NEVER STOPS.
that's this bosses main problem. When Paired with the Clunky Firing, you have a boss that's very hard to hit and moves fast, which is  problem when you need to send your arrow throgh fire to kill it. Fire that has to be activated by buttons. that only the brain can activate. A brain that NEVER STOPS. It can also Jump accorss the room and, if you remember, EVERYTHING is a 1HKO. As you can Imagine, It's Annyingly Hard, and not fun at all.
But, if that was the only ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t I Encountered, I would have continued Playing.
Vut, Considering the fact this review is going up, that's sadly not the case.

The 4th, and Most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t Boss, is the Lazer Block. The lazer block is... a Block that shoots lazers from an Eye on one side. Every few flips, the lazer fires. In order to Kill it, I Assume you hit the Eye with the arrow. I say assume because this Boss is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Take the worst Aspects of the Ice brain Fight and Multiply them by ten, and you have the lazer Cube Fight. Not only does the Cube move so fast Sonic would say 'Wow, that's slightly faster then the Average person.

reviewText:
I hate this game.

I keep going back to play it to try and have some fun. The bosses seem hard, and it is one hit kill, but finding out their patterns usually leads pretty quickly to their death.

Problem is, you might get killed trying to figure out their patterns/weakness. When you die, you go back to the beginning of the whole game world, and you have to keep running back to the boss. The instant death, combined with the repetitive trek back to stupid boss to try again is obnoxious.

I'm sure things get more interesting, and I would love to see what this game has to offer. Unfortunately, the actual act of playing it is too tedious to waste my time with.

reviewText:
I hate this game.

I keep going back to play it to try and have some fun. The bosses seem hard, and it is one hit kill, but finding out their patterns usually leads pretty quickly to their death.

Problem is, you might get killed trying to figure out their patterns/weakness. When you die, you go back to the beginning of the whole game world, and you have to keep running back to the boss. The instant death, combined with the repetitive trek back to stupid boss to try again is obnoxious.

I'm sure things get more interesting, and I would love to see what this game has to offer. Unfortunately, the actual act of playing it is too tedious to waste my time with.

And if you appreciate music, aesthetics and design, this game could be for you.\n\nTitan Souls is an open world game. reviewText:
It'll start of by letting you know: The majority of the negative reviews are people who can't beat the first bosses. They were not expecting a challenge or even watched a video of this game. But as the Dark Souls community says: GET GOOD.

If you enjoy Shadow of the Colossus or you're an appraiser of challenging oldschool games, you'll enjoy Titan Souls!

Really simple and solid gameplay, beautifull graphics and landscapes (even being so small and minimalist) and great OST.

I definetilly advise it to anyone who has a controller (semi-impossible to play on keyboard).

I had a lot of fun, but in less than 6 hours i already beat the game, and i have no plans of playing it harder for now. I paid arround 3 dollars on it and i wish i had paid more.

If you're willing to buy this game, keep in mind that it is really simple and short! You'll spend most of your time figuring out how to and trying to beat the bosses. You'll die a lot (i died 188 times uniti i beat the game).

It's one of my favorite games now!

reviewText:
I really didn't want to say that Titan Souls is a 2D Shadow of the Colossus, but Titan Souls is a 2D Shadow of the Colossus. The controls are smooth and the world looks wonderful, and each boss has two real stages - the part where you work out the puzzle that is 'How do I kill this Titan?' and the part where you then have to execute that plan.

It's the execution that can prove frustrating. If you're prone to rage-quiting or lacking in patience, then this game isn't for you. Simple slip ups are punished harshly, and although the checkpoints aren't far from each Titan, the 20-45second treck can get tedious when it's the third, or fourth, or fifth time in a row.

If you can perservere through the trial and error, however, the game is quite rewarding and it's very satisfying to finally take down that Titan you've been stuck on.

reviewText:
I'm seeing a lot of bad reviews for this game. I personally absolutely loved it! I see the main point negative reviews are making are the time it takes to return to a boss fight. It's never more than 10 seconds to walk to one, so I don't quite understand that, if anything it gives you a bit of time to cool off, haha. The bosses are difficult, but the whole point of this game is the trial and error nature of the gameplay. You may die 20 times trying to figure out a boss, but once you stay alive long enough to work out it's movement pattern, you're only one shot away from victory. And boy, is victory satisfying.

9/10 I had a great day playing this.

reviewText:
Maybe I shouldn't be writing this right after rage quitting. But I am still recommending it. Keep in mind I haven't finished playing it yet.

A game 90% boss fights and 10% walking around, one-hit kills, both for you and the bosses. This means the battles are extremely short. You start, die, maybe learn something, try again until you kill it. That is a compelling idea! But all this repetition is extremely tedious because you don't respawn fast and near the boss. And if we learned anything from Super MeatBoy is that repetition is ok if it doesn't waste my time. Dark souls sends you back too, sure, but the path is full of perils and challenges so you have something to do at least.

So this is where I find myself: I fought against a boss about 5 times, the boss itself is a compelling puzzle and a reflex challenge, and I WANT to try again. But every time the game sends me back I want to simply close the game. It's the walking from spawn position back to the boss that kills the pacing of the game because  it takes LONGER to walk over there than the fight itself.

But anyway. Yes, the game looks very pretty, the Titans are very well designed, figuring them out is fun, finally beating them is very rewarding. If you are a very, very patient person and are totally ok with the walking part (seriously, your thumb will gain muscle memory and you can do the path with your eyes closed) then you will love this game.

One final nitpick: why isn't run the standard state? who walks? My A button is starting to make noises.

reviewText:
Titan Souls is clearly a labour of love by the developers behind it, but it's a game that was far better on paper than to actually play. I was surprised at how fast I grew to dislike this game.

The mechanics of combat are basically redefined for each boss, and  you are expected via trial and error to figure them out. If you die you get sent to a respawn point which can be an agonizing slog back to the boss door.  The movement and polish are finnicky enough that you could spend a while pursuing the right solution, only to have it fail mysteriously and get stuck not knowing if you were close to the answer or not.

Boss combat is like trying a bunch of keys to unlock a door that just sticks randomly sometimes, and if you get it wrong you have to walk around the house three times.

This is just a fundamentally broken design loop.  You can't have trial and error gameplay with punishment. It's basically the worst parts of every boss fight in every game distilled into one game.

I would actually recommend the game to developers just so they can identify what this does wrong so they never do it in their own boss fights. The game may actually be more fun if you look at a FAQ which would remove the worst of the trial and error aspects of the game.
