reviewText:
The top reviews say it all.
It tries to be a combination of Dark Souls and Shadow of the Collosus except it failsat recreating the greatest traits of either. The atmosphere is nice and the music and art do their job well, but the lack of worldbuilding and motivation at the start makes it a drag to care about anything you're doing. There is absolutely nothing at the beginning, it just throws you in because you're playing a video game, now play the video game dammit, kill these things because they impede forward progress and literally nothing else. I got more out of the story from the breif description of the game on the store page then the time i spent with this game.
It lacks the scale and wonder of Shadow of the Colossus when it comes to the environments and exploration. It also lacks the intimidating nature and granduer of its boss fights as Titan Souls beleives in quantity over quality. The bosses are nothing more than a thirty second chaotic mess to see who hits who first instead of a puzzle that needed to be overcome.
When it comes to difficulty, it looked at Dark Souls for maybe five seconds and decided that making everything tough as nails is the best way to make your game challenging and rewarding. In reality, it only frustrates the player as they spend more time walking back to the fight then actually engaged in it and once the player lands a lucky shot it is instantly over and you end up feeling nothing for beating the creature.
If the game focused more on a smaller number of fights that were longer and more challenging then just a one hit lucky strike and tried to do more with its story and world, then I'd be able to recommend Titan Souls. But, that's not what the game is, so I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Beat the game's main 16 bosses in about 2 and a half hours, don't plan on picking the game up again.

I don't mind hard games - in fact, the Dark Souls series are some of my favorite games. The reason that I don't recommend this game doesn't have to do with it being hard.

I got this game because I love boss fights, so I figured it was right up my alley. I quickly found that the bosses in this game don't have the same feel of all of those boss fights that I love. You die in one hit, which I am quite okay with. However, most of the bosses also die in one hit if you manage to hit them at the right time, so it turns would could be very epic battles against titanic bosses into what feels like dumb luck and removes any sort of feeling of accomplishment when you do beat them.

I remember fighting one of the bosses who had killed me two or three times and I was devising a strategy to avoid one of his stronger attacks that he uses throughout the fight. Except the next time I fought him I got off a lucky potshot after his first attack and killed him in one hit. It didn't feel rewarding, it just felt lucky, and honestly, I walked away from it feeling a little robbed.

To contrast this game with those of the Souls games and Shadow of the Colossus, both of which this game takes inspiration from, what this game really lacks is a sense of accomplishment for taking down the bosses/titans. In the other games I mentioned, the player, weak compared to these gargantuan creatures, manages to take them down against all odds. In Titan Souls, you don't get that. Because while the Titans may have different and more lethal attacks than you do, in reality they are just as weak as you are. And since most of their weak points are only momentarily visible, a lot of the time, at least in my case, it felt that it was just a lucky shot that ended most battles.

reviewText:
Titan Souls is a fun little game in which you play as a character with a single arrow. You use this arrow to take down giant beasts, giving the game a Shadow of the Colossus feel. Controls are pretty good with a gamepad although i'd imagine it being very frustrating with just a keyboard due to directional control being integral to how you aim your arrows.

The game is pretty much a boss rush, and each enemy kills you in one hit (and likewise, you typically kill them in one as well). You can complete the game in quite a short amount of time, so I'd recommend waiting to purchase this until it's on sale, as a $15 price point is ridiculous for a game that may last some little more than two hours. Sure, you can redo the game on harder difficulties and go achievement hunting, but for the most part the rush that comes from figuring out how to kill a boss dies away after your first completion. Another complaint is that respawning takes a bit of time, which is a little annoying when you have to walk up to boss rooms and can get killed in a matter of seconds (at least 1/4 of my playtime was waiting for the screen to go black and returning to a boss encounter room). Along with this, while the bosses are on an epic scale, the one hit kills sort of work against the game in some cases. I've had random shots kill some bosses, which made the fights very anticlimactic. Since most bosses require precision, I didn't feel elated that I got a random shot, just like I cheated the game and didn't deserve the victory. Others may feel differently in such a situation.

The score is well done and the art conveys the boss characters well. Story wise there's not really much going on (from my playthrough anyway), although there are like murals on walls that I suppose are supposed to tell some sort of story if you pay enough attention to them?

Get this game if you're looking for a challenging little boss-rush game to play through, but make sure to wait until it goes on sale. If you're looking for something with a strong story or a lot to do, look somewhere else.

And it chould be frustrating. If you take 1 hit your dead. But you dont loose your progress. Nothing like a Game Over here.

The Bosses are really good and it makes fun to destroy them over and over again.

But is this Game for you? I found myself trying to Run" this Game as fast as possible. And it was fun to trying it. To get a taktic for every Boss and even try the most Frameperfect Kills is really challenging.
If you never did something like this before - this chould be your first Game. When you got into it its about 16-30 min of a full play through (depends on mode and or any%). I found this short enught for me and still very challenging.

But you dont need to trying to Speedrun this Game. Just playing it normal and trying to beat it is huge fun.

I really recommend this Game to everybody who is interested in Speed Runs or just playing a hard Game and trying to beat it.

And something which is on the Forums for ...FOREVER... TB (Total Biscuit) reviewed this Game. And he didnt found it very good. Which is ok. Couz i think nobody likes everything. Even when its well executed.
I dont like Fallout 4.... so? Stone me? NO... Its just what i like and not like.
BUT... there was a pretty huge Sh*tstorm couz the developers ( I GUESS ) reacted with some pretty bad manners to TB Review. This shouldnt happen... but tbh they made a good game. And its worth picking up.
You guys keep flaming EA and Ubisoft ... but keep buying the Games.... so yea... just my point.

so I AM really like this Game and i whould recommend it.
Aaaaand im not a Dev - wasnt payed for this or something ^^"

reviewText: One of the most fun, most difficult games you will ever play. This game is so ridiculously hard that it's hilarious! Enemies don't attack you until you attack them, but once you do, you're f***ed. You have one arrow, which you must retrieve after every shot, but there are ways to make the fights easier if you're observant. While the game is absurdly hard, it still doesn't feel unfair.

reviewText:
Tl;dr - Game is entirely boss fights. Bosses are unique and fun. Fast-paced, battles can be won or lost very quickly. Controller is recommended, but absolutely not required.


The game is entirely boss fights. These fights end in either one well-placed arrow against the boss, or one well-placed hit on you (with a couple exceptions). It can feel a bit underwhelming when you beat a boss because of this, but it's okay! There's a solution! It's called a whoooole library full of bosses. There's a damn lot of them, and they're all unique and hard to fight.

The game is played with minimal backstory (Did I say minimal? I meant it's not there.)

Controls are very tight, which is good, because the only way to beat the boss you're fighting might be to fire and arrow in between floating fists zooming around that can either block your arrow from their target or just pancake you.

Music is pretty 'aight

Basic Controls:
Can quickly move a short distance by rolling
Shoot an arrow, aim using controller or arrow keys
Can use the force to make your arrow fly back to your hand, this can damage enemies and is sometimes the only way to beat them
AAAH! I'M SUPPOSED TO PLAY WITH A CONTROLLER!?" The game is meant to be played with a controller ("highly recommended") But certainly not required! With a controller

reviewText: A game with a solid core mechanic, great aesthetic and atmosphere, and a well-executed implied narrative and setting. Very much in the vein of ICO and Shadow of the Colossus, but a much more distilled experience with less filler/padding. This is precisely what good game design is all about. Witcher 3, MGSV, Order 1886 may have had spectacular visuals and art direction (and crazy good animation and insanely good cinematographic direction in the latter two cases), but Titan Souls is a better classic than any of them, because it is a solid concept executed well.

reviewText:
An overall visually appealing platform on which a breath of fresh air has been served. Accompanied by a captivating soundtrack that will dull the hours, no wait, minutes (they seem like hours) of walking to and from the extremely long save point locations.

If you love pixel-graphics, an intruiging story and challenging gameplay, then dig deeper and make sure you do posses these traits, because this game will test every fibre of your patience and fortitude in order to enjoy its content.

I think its worth it, overall.

reviewText:
Amazing atmosphere. Thrilling boss battles. Nothing but boss battles, in fact. Every victory feels like an accomplishment, as you have spent time backtracking and dying over and over until you finally get in that one shot. A lot of the reviews list this as a negative; I would argue that it's a positive. If you could just restart a battle instantly, death really wouldn't have a meaning, you might as well just make the player invincible. You have to spend 10-15 seconds (literally, that's all it usually takes) to get back to a boss area after you die. Do people not know how to activate the checkpoint seals?

It'd be nice to have a bit more to do, the world is beautiful and fun to explore, but eventually you start to realize that mostly all you're going to find is more pretty stuff to look at. This is another thing that I consider more or less a positive, though: the game knows where its focus is, and it does it well, even masterfully. This is a game where it's nearly impossible to feel bad while playing it. I found myself fighting and dying to the same boss over and over for about an hour and a half, and never once did it start feeling like work. The atmosphere is so enthralling and I was just so focused on thinking of different strategies, different vulnerabilities in its attack patterns, that I hardly noticed I had done more or less the same thing who knows how many times.

And when you finally get in that killing shot? That's the most heart-stopping, fist-pounding, %$#& YOU I GOT YOU!" moment possible in a video game

reviewText:
I want to like this game, I love the idea, respect the strongly focused design, and think the visuals are gorgeous.  Unfortunately, a few note worthy flaws mean the execution leaves something to be desired.

Firstly, despite being released on PC at the same time as PS4, it has clearly been designed for console, leaving the PC version feeling like a mediocre port.  It controls poorly without a gamepad, because the joystick (used for both movement and aiming) is replaced with the arrow keys, which means you can only really aim in 8 different directions.  This, of course, could have been solved with some modifications to include the mouse in the control scheme, but was not.

Another problem is the respawn times.  Yes.  I got it.  I died again.  I don't need to watch the screen fade to black as a behemoth continues to jump up and down on my bloody husk every ♥♥♥♥ing time, especially not if you're going to follow that up with making me walk all the way back to the boss room I just died in.

Edit:  Got a steam controller and the game is very fun now.  Still only recommend if you have some sort of gamepad, but I felt I should note that it works very well if you do actually have one.

reviewText:
Amazing atmosphere. Thrilling boss battles. Nothing but boss battles, in fact. Every victory feels like an accomplishment, as you have spent time backtracking and dying over and over until you finally get in that one shot. A lot of the reviews list this as a negative; I would argue that it's a positive. If you could just restart a battle instantly, death really wouldn't have a meaning, you might as well just make the player invincible. You have to spend 10-15 seconds (literally, that's all it usually takes) to get back to a boss area after you die. Do people not know how to activate the checkpoint seals?

It'd be nice to have a bit more to do, the world is beautiful and fun to explore, but eventually you start to realize that mostly all you're going to find is more pretty stuff to look at. This is another thing that I consider more or less a positive, though: the game knows where its focus is, and it does it well, even masterfully. This is a game where it's nearly impossible to feel bad while playing it. I found myself fighting and dying to the same boss over and over for about an hour and a half, and never once did it start feeling like work. The atmosphere is so enthralling and I was just so focused on thinking of different strategies, different vulnerabilities in its attack patterns, that I hardly noticed I had done more or less the same thing who knows how many times.

And when you finally get in that killing shot? That's the most heart-stopping, fist-pounding, %$#& YOU I GOT YOU!" moment possible in a video game

reviewText:
This game is one of the toughest games I played in a while. I still have to kill a few more bosses in the game and that is the best thing about this game. I love the challenge in this game. But to the review!

Story: You are a guy with a one bow and arrow versing bosses for some strange and unknown reason. I like that there is a simple concept to it. Not every game needs an enriching story so this is fine for me. However, since the world is pretty big, I would have liked to have seen some sort of lore to the world plastered on to the wall.

Graphics: The pixel graphics look great. It has a good artstyle.

Sound: The sound design is beautiful. Some might say it is simplistic, but I think that works great for this game. The music makes you feel like you are at peace when you die after a boss. It makes the world you are in seem more mysterious. I'm glad that they chose this track or else I probably would have been rage quitting most of the time after the bosses kill me. Not every game needs to have a totally memorable track.

Gameplay: This is where the game truly shines. The bosses are hard as balls. At first the game starts you off with 4 pretty simple bosses. It is a one hit KO for each boss you face, but they also one hit KO you. ( You are more likely going to die first). The first few bosses set up what the game is going to be like. Each boss is some sort of puzzle that you need to figure out. Their weak spots aren't hidden, but are hard to get to. Most likely you will only have a split second to attack. Some might say this is terrible game design, but I don't think so. The thing is when you do hit the boss, I feel so empowered and ready to kill the next titan. I think the game rewards you for being good at the game. Each shot will take a lot of precision and skill, which is what makes this game so great.

Overall, this game is great if you are looking for a challenge. The game is sort of like Shadow of Colossus with Dark Souls difficulty mixed in with Zelda puzzles to kill the bosses. The gameplay is challenging and also rewarding when you hit the mark. If you die, the soundtrack relaxes you and makes you come back for me. Put a great pixel art design and you have a done deal. Note: This game isn't for people who rage a lot.

This game focuses on two things and does them fantasticly.

reviewText: This is a very good game, no doubt about it, but there are quite a bit of issues that should be adressed. First off, the controls are TERRIBLE, and there is no way to rebind keys in a game that came out in 2015! The controls could have been great: WASD to move, left mouse for arrow (use mouse to aim), and right mouse or space for roll. Instead, however, you use the arrow keys to move and X&C to shoot and roll, respectively. Who though this was a good idea? It's quite uncomfortable, and I often found myself pressing the wrong button, causing me to die. Because you die so often and so quickly, It would be nice if you spawned in front of the titan you last fought, to avoid the annoyance of running the same path to fight the same titan over and over. I would recommend this game, but only of it's on a good sale and you have a controller.

reviewText:
This is a nice game. The visuals are amazing, and the soundtrack is beautiful. It's like a 2D Shadow of the Colossus.

The gameplay is simple, you have to show an arrow into the enemy weak spot to kill him, but you can only do this when you aren't moving, and the titans can also kill you with one attack. I won't say the game is easy, mostly because of the one hit kill, but it's also not that hard. After you know how the titan behave is simple to know how to hit it's weak spot.

One point that i think the game lacks, is the absense of a story, and although it worked very well with Shadow of the Colossus, here it just makes you think that it's missing something. The game is also very short, and i don't find much of a replayabillity.

I would say that 10€ would be a fair price for this game, mostly due to the fact you only need a couple of hours to finish it the first time. Still, i recommend it.

reviewText:
Titan Souls is a fun little game in which you play as a character with a single arrow. You use this arrow to take down giant beasts, giving the game a Shadow of the Colossus feel. Controls are pretty good with a gamepad although i'd imagine it being very frustrating with just a keyboard due to directional control being integral to how you aim your arrows.

The game is pretty much a boss rush, and each enemy kills you in one hit (and likewise, you typically kill them in one as well). You can complete the game in quite a short amount of time, so I'd recommend waiting to purchase this until it's on sale, as a $15 price point is ridiculous for a game that may last some little more than two hours. Sure, you can redo the game on harder difficulties and go achievement hunting, but for the most part the rush that comes from figuring out how to kill a boss dies away after your first completion. Another complaint is that respawning takes a bit of time, which is a little annoying when you have to walk up to boss rooms and can get killed in a matter of seconds (at least 1/4 of my playtime was waiting for the screen to go black and returning to a boss encounter room). Along with this, while the bosses are on an epic scale, the one hit kills sort of work against the game in some cases. I've had random shots kill some bosses, which made the fights very anticlimactic. Since most bosses require precision, I didn't feel elated that I got a random shot, just like I cheated the game and didn't deserve the victory. Others may feel differently in such a situation.

The score is well done and the art conveys the boss characters well. Story wise there's not really much going on (from my playthrough anyway), although there are like murals on walls that I suppose are supposed to tell some sort of story if you pay enough attention to them?

Get this game if you're looking for a challenging little boss-rush game to play through, but make sure to wait until it goes on sale. If you're looking for something with a strong story or a lot to do, look somewhere else.

reviewText: A game with a solid core mechanic, great aesthetic and atmosphere, and a well-executed implied narrative and setting. Very much in the vein of ICO and Shadow of the Colossus, but a much more distilled experience with less filler/padding. This is precisely what good game design is all about. Witcher 3, MGSV, Order 1886 may have had spectacular visuals and art direction (and crazy good animation and insanely good cinematographic direction in the latter two cases), but Titan Souls is a better classic than any of them, because it is a solid concept executed well.

reviewText:
Art and Music - Absolutely beautifully done, and prefectly fits the setting and tone.

Story - To call it 'non-existent' would be false, but it's functionally non-existent.

Gameplay - This is where the meat of the game is, whether it passes or fails for you. In a sparce (but very pretty) setting there are a number of rooms each with a different boss in them. Each boss is at once a test of timing, aiming, and deduction as you try to figure out exactly how to kill it. You will die a lot, but each death brings you one stop closer to beating the boss, either through figuring out how you're meant to kill it, or getting the timing/aim just right.

This game is certainly not for everyone, it is only for people who get a sense of extreme satisfaction for overcoming very difficult challenges. Would recommend watching a video that goes through some of the early gameplay before you decide to pick this one up.

The most beautifully polished turd on steam.

This game is just as fun as playing the entire legend of zelda, link to the past with no map, no items, no weapons, and only 1/2 a heart.

it should be renamed to walk to the titan shrine over and over until you fluke a kill; and get happy only because you never have to play that ♥♥♥♥ing part of the game again"... longer title... more descriptive of actual gameplay.

i hate to say the game is too hard ... because i play all my games in hard mode... it's just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI programming...

i can move 2 spaces per second... monster can move 11 ... you lose.... reload ... walk to shrine ... repeat.
sometimes ... fire an arrow .... then get smashed while you stand still summoning it back .... repeat ...
sometimes fire an arrow and miss completely even though it passed completely throught the enemy sprite... repeat
sometimes run near an enemy ... get smashed becasue your hit box is 44x the size of your sprite.... repeat...

repreat repeat repeat.....
then get lucky and move on to the next section you will play 3000x"

reviewText:
Awesome boss fights, great game idea! However, you will spend more time walking to the fights, than you will spend fighting. Recommended if you like traversing the same piece of map over and over.

If you do decide to get this game, you'll get great boss fights that will leave you frustrated until you get an epiphany. And then you’ll be frustrated while walking back to the boss trying to execute your new plan, because that is what you’re going to be doing. Walking back to great boss fights!

Please note, I’ve played this game more than what is logged on steam (Humble Bundle).

reviewText:
Pros:
-artstyle pretty good
-good OST

Cons:

reviewText:
I came into this game expecting crazy rolling and impossibly fast arrows flying anywhich direction while being swrmed by enemies. I was sorely mistaken. The pace and timing of the game with it's enemies the TITANS all attacking you with unique attacks in different patterns and speeds were a huge challenge I was not expecting. The gameplay is fun as you have a new problem at each titan and the large treks you must take between boss' to find them I found largely enjoyable due to the gorgeous pixelated landscape. The treks between where you respawn and to the boss while shorter than going to region to region did get boring. Sound in this game has been masterfully orchestrated to provide a none too dull experience as you are pelted by the titans and a calm reprieve as you travel the lands so that is a godsend as I thought this game would have a high pitched non-stop enthusiastic 80's track and that would have killed me more than my 745 ingame deaths.

To sum it up this game with its lovely aesthetics, engaging combat, easy to pick up controls if you use an xbox360 or PS3 remote (I did not use the keyboard as the game sugested; don't let me stop you though) and the sense of achievement that so rarely come from playing tripleA games make this an exceptional purchase for those who wish to buy something simple. It is hard, but only because we aren't used to games like this don't let me forget.

After this review I will try and get the rest of the games achievements and maybe become a start streaming this game HAHA ;).

reviewText:
this game is great and im loving it.

but i have one huge gripe.

the keyboard controlls are not coustomizable and the game has better aim using a controller (360 degree vs. 8 direction).
no custom layouts is BS on a game on PC.

the controller has pretty much all its buttions as mutiple layouts dpad/analog, then most of the buttions including the bumpers.
keyboard gets one layout ... arrow keys and XC.....

if you wanna play with WASD then you better go find some of the auto hot key scripts on the fourms for this game.

while the game looks nice its missing core features that should be in every game weather its a AAA title or an indie game.

this comes off as a lazy PSVita port.

game is great but i do not reccomend it.

reviewText:
I got this game on sale, $4.  I really recommend buying it now just because its like 50% off for the original price $16. (All CA$)

Remember: I only have 2 hours played, everything I say may be incorrect.

This game is hard, you only have the one arrow which you always have to retrieve.
If you enjoy games where you need a different  strategy for each enemy, which so far are all different.
2 hours in, I died 100 times (there are checkpoints).
Every time I killed a boss, I felt like I accomplished something, its a great feeling.
The Titan Souls world is very nice thought 2d can look kinda weird; the story is blurry but I can tell it`s one of those games with a rich lore.
The only real downside I see is that there isn't much between the boss fights.
There are no enemies, (only bosses) but luckily there are some head scratching puzzles.
I personally wish there were individual enemies between boss fights, but I understand why not.
You also stick with you character and weapons probably the whole game, so probably no customization or different weapons throughout the game.

Overall a very fun game, feels very achieving, it does make you rage though. Watch out for that.

reviewText:
Considering Shadow of the Colossus is my favorite game of all time, Titan Souls definitely doesn't top that but it is similar in many ways, thus being a pretty nice game. Although the game is fairly short, I enjoyed the game even though I finished it in barely 3 hours.

Pros:
+ Great soundtrack.
+ Good graphical style even though its pixel-based.
+ General combat mechanic is pretty cool, almost every titan goes down with a single hit, but that goes for you as well.
+ If you're struggling with a titan, you're not forced to beat it as you could just go somewhere else and start fighting another titan (Eventually you'll need to beat every titan in an area however, you can beat the titans in that area in any order you like).
+ When you complete the game for the first time, you will unlock a couple of difficulty-increasing gamemodes, such as Hard mode, Iron mode (1 death = Permanent game over) and the No run/rolling mode.
+ Some pretty hardcore achievements which definitely leaves a good challenge for those who wish to take them on.

Cons:
- Game is pretty short, therefore I think the game should of had at least 10 more titans to be worth the full price.
- The world is pretty small. At first it will seem huge, but the closer you get to the end you will start realizing how small the world really is.
- Not really much of a story to the game. For example, at the end of a fight when you beat a titan you absorb its soul, but this doesn't do anything at all.

reviewText:
This game is really good. You can just tell by the trailers that the devs put a lot of time into this game.

This review will be split up into - The Good, The Bad, The Ideas.


The Good
+Pixel art is really well done.
+Music is AMAZING. Sometimes I try to survive as long as I can, in a boss fight, to hear the music.
+There's a death counter. You know you're in for a good one when you have that.
+Gamplay is simple, shoot an arrow into the bosses' weak point, if you miss, retrive it.
+Frusteratingly fun.
+When you defeat a boss, your brain leaks satisfaction.
+Challenging achivements.
+More than 1 mode.
+Defeat all bosses in any order you'd like.

The Bad
-It's kinda short.
-Some achivements and bosses can be VERY, VERY frusterating.
-Sorta luck based (20%), sometimes you actually can defeat a boss from a blind shot.
-Overworld is very bland, and tiny.


The Ideas
*Some sort of expansion pack (free or paid) to add a little more story, bosses, etc.
*Steam trading cards, and backrounds, PRETTY PLEASE?

Quick Note:
There's actually a story to this game. You have to dig deep for it though. Thanks to MadMev for helping me find it!

This game is really, really good. Worth buying for the full price.

Final Score:
7.8/10 - Awesome!

reviewText:
Do you like fighting bosses? Do you like exploration? Do you like actually having to think before you attack? Then you'll like this game.

The game's focus is on bosses, and the bosses are very good. Each boss is well-designed and unique; a few of them are rehashes of concepts you've seen before in other games, but the majority feel fresh and new. Emphasis is always on dodging and manouvering and waiting for the right time to strike. In fact, every boss can be killed in one hit to their weak point, but might take dozens of tries before you figure out how to do it.

That said, a few of the bosses require either ridiculously precise timing (like, less than a quarter of a second), and the final boss is entirely luck-based (the only strategies" involve exploiting a weird quirk in his AI). The saving grace is that again
date:
you only have to nail that timing once to kill the boss.

Inbetween bosses you'll explore some beautiful scenery. Every area has unique sights to see and was created with intricate detail; they vary from ruins to forests to a volcano and a frozen mountain. Your character's footsteps even vary depending on the ground you're walking (or running) on. Checkpoints give you clues as to the number and direction of nearby bosses.

There's also a phenomenal soundtrack
recommended: both in and out of battle; everry boss has its own song.\n\nThe one thing that I consider bad is the keyboard control. Most of the game can be beaten just fine with a keyboard
hoursPlayed: but there's a few bosses where it's much
voteText: much harder than a gamepad due to not being able to fire in any direction. When a boss's weak point is open for less than a second after an attack
helpfulPercent: 8 directions doesn't cut it.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: I highly recomend this game to anyone who likes killing creative and unique bosses. Which is hopefully everybody."

reviewText: A Shadow of the Colossus esque game with a near Dark Soulsian style of storytelling, sign me right up.\nThis game's pretty much about pure skill and using what few abilities you have to pull off the impossible. The one hit kills and one hit deaths make the game extremely tense at almost every battle, coming at it over and over, figuring out a way to win, it's an interesting learning curve but it can be intensely frustrating, especially towards the end. But that frustration is worth it in the end for that sheer sense of accomplishment.\nThe environment design is excellent, it might be a bit big and walking back to bosses can get a bit frustrating, but the way it's set out, some neat background details that help tell parts of the story, it genuinely feels like you're walking around a long forgotten world. The tidbits of story you pick up, especially when replaying after unlocking a certain mode, create an interesting Fill in the gaps" kind of deal that
recommended:
reminds me of Dark souls.
Soundtrack is also excellent. I especially like how the boss music can start at two different places so it doesn't get too stale for the short time you get to enjoy it.

Overall
hoursPlayed: it's an atmospheric experience of a game that
voteText: if you like boss battles

reviewText:
Rarely do I play a game where I both love it and love hating it. I just finished the game in No Roll mode after a couple of hours of wanting to punch my monitor. I normally do these reviews after all the achievements, but I can only imagine it taking me a few more weeks before I can claim the Iron + Hard Mode achievement. I had to use a guide for some of the achievement kills, especially the glitched one on the gate keeper titan in the starting area. These achievements are brutal and not for the faint of heart. My Dark Souls days prepared me for this game, but it was still frustratingly difficult. If you're a masochist, you'll enjoy the added gamemodes.

As for the rest of the game, the mechanics are inspired by and almost identical to dark souls in which you roll and roll and roll and roll and maybe land a hit on the titan. The first time through will probably be difficult without help, but not so much you will never be able to continue. The graphics are your stereotypical 2D pixel art found in indie games, but I feel like they fit this game well. The art had a sort of charm to it but it wasn't anything new to me.

I'll give this game 8/10 with a warning that you'll either love this game enough to finish it once, love this game enough to eventually hate yourself with the extra modes, or hate this game and wonder why masochists enjoy this type of thing.

reviewText:
The game needs another tuning pass, then it'd be a hands-down masterpiece. As it is, it's more infuriatingly difficult than rewardingly. TL;DR: Recommended only for semi-sadists. This isn't as good as the games its inspired by (currently).

You have a run button, but you pretty much HAVE to hold it down, since the normal walk speed is a surefire way to get yourself killed.
The arrow is alright, but if you miss your shot, you're pretty much dead, since it takes too long to retrieve it.
The music is fantastic, but you'll only ever hear the first 6 seconds of a given song, because either you or the boss will be dead by then.


NEEDED TWEAKS FOR GREATNESS
* Double the speed of the arrow retrieval, at least in its acceleration curve.
* Allow some movement (50% penalty?) while retrieving.
* Make run speed 20% faster
* Make walk speed 80% of what run speed is now
* Eliminate tiny delay before your arrow shoots. A short press should still launch an arrow, not do nothing.
* Arrow distance curve should increase. You have to hold the button a bit longer than feels right to get a 'usable' distance out of it.
* Increase magnet radius for arrow retrieval. The archer has ONE JOB. Let's make it easy for him to do it.
* Second-to-last boss needs to telegraph where he's going to go. It feels way too random and unpredictable. HIs window should also be about 250 ms wider, or it should be faster to nock/target the arrow. As it is, you just have to aim early and hope.
* Swap blob boss and box boss as the box is a LOT easier and a better 'first' boss to encounter.

OPTIONAL:
* Add some degree of health, at least ONE hit of forgiveness, on the first playthrough. (though may not be as necessary if the tweaks above are applied).
* Switch to a more standard rule of threes" approach with yet more HPs to the player
date: like a permanent 3. We get to hear more music
recommended: and we get to have a more epic
hoursPlayed: less random chancey encounter."

reviewText:
Extremely hard at first, you die without realising it.
But it's very challenging, the game is like a succession of really hard boss and each time you've got to study them and find their weak spot and the timing to strike it.
It's hard but possible ! That's what I like with this game is despite the fact that each boss seems really hard, it's not impossible to beat them, you just have to try again and again.
Then you get better so you can re-do the boss in far less death than before. And also if you want some real challenge you can try the achievments (some are insanely hard) or re-do the game in harder modes.

It's really enjoyable to try beat a boss for one hour and then finally strike the final blow ! That's rewarding :)
The music and graphics are also very good !

reviewText:
Titan Souls is a pixel art top down action adventure game. You play as a little boy with a bow and a single arrow. You can shoot and summon this one arrow. The game takes place in an open world where you discover and solve light puzzles to find boss rooms. You fight around twenty bosses in eight different areas to clear the game.

The bosses are quite unique from one another and extremely challenging. Each boss has an achievement tied to it where you would have to kill a boss in 5 seconds, or some other insane goal before ending the encounter. Every boss has one weak spot and only takes a single shot to defeat.

I cleared the game with a few achievements unlocked at around 6 hours with around 100+ deaths. Once you complete the game you can take that same character back into the world where all bosses will be alive again in their rooms, this is great for achievement completion and speed run practice.


There are other modes that unlock upon completion as well. Hardcore mode, one life mode and a mode that disables running and your evasive roll move. So all in all I highly recommend this game to anyone that likes a challenge its also great for the speedrunners and achievement hunters.

reviewText:
Titan Souls is an enjoyable, albeit short game with a nice pixel art style and good music that suits the game very well. The gameplay is very similar to Shadow of the Colossus in that the only enemies you fight are boss like creatures that require you to find their weak spot and hit it with your arrow. Although you only need to hit their weak spot once, you also die in one hit, which is where most of the games difficulty comes from.

The Good:
As mentioned above, the art style is good and adds a nice atmosphere to the game with a great soundtrack that goes along with it, that includes peaceful music while exploring and looking for the bosses, and switches to a faster pace and more intense piece when fighting a boss. The controls feel fluid while running around and fighting, and only having one arrow to work with makes you have to plan when and how to use each shot. Since your arrow is also soul linked" to you
date: it is possible to attract the arrow back to you after you shoot it
recommended: adding another element of strategy as you can hit the bosses by doing so. Each boss is unique and finding each of their weak spots is part of the challenge that makes fighting a new boss even more enjoyable. Managing to finally figure out how to defeat a boss and landing the precise shot to kill it is a very satifying experience. The difficulty of the game remains challenging but never becomes overly hard
hoursPlayed:
and includes 3 new modes after you complete the story that increase the difficulty if you want more of a challenge.

The Bad:
Alhtough the environments look nice

reviewText: A wonderfully pure gaming experience. The game is simple - kill the titans, absorb their souls. To be honest when I put it like that I'm not entirely sure we're not the bad guy in this narrative. The mechanics are equally simplistic, you have one arrow and Titans have one weak spot, find it, exploit it, kill it. The game is clearly inspired by Shadow Of The Colussus and in my opinion does an even better job of creating varied and interesting bosses. I found myself smiling often at this game's ingenuity, those satisfying moments when you figure out a Titan's achilles heel and the rush when you just know you're gonna' take it down next time. The pixel graphics are beautiful, there's a real sense of intelligent art design behind every environment and every Titan, it really feels like a passion project. Equal plaudits go to the soundtrack which is just exceptional, up there with Transistor as one of my favourites of the past 12 months. Normally after beating a game like this once I'll put it down and that's that but already I'm tempted to pick Titan Souls up again and try it with one of the gimmicky replay modes like No Roll or Iron Man. For those arguing there's not much to this game I'd argue there doesn't need to be, perhaps it's a quibble on price point but as a game I think it has everything it needs to.

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game.
It is a good looking game, most of the bosses look very cool and the music is great.
However, you hardly get to listen to the music because a boss fight usually lasts 5 - 15 seconds.
The difficulty is another thing that has annoyed me about it. I'm close to the end, maybe 1 or 2 bosses left and I have not enjoyed it. At first I thought that it was just one of those games you go in figure the bosses weakness then try again and again to get it right, which it is. However, when you die you respawn, nothing else happens, therefore dying doesn't have a consequence. You die, you respawn, you walk, you fight, you die. That is the game.
For the price, it's not worth it at all, if you are a completionist then you might replay it, but you get maybe 3 - 5 hours out of it and that's you done.
So far I have gotten no reward for killing the bosses. All you do it kill one, then go kill the next untill you have killed them all.
I feel that I am playing this game just to complete it, get it out of the way then uninstall it.
Though many many people enjoyed the game, I didn't, I don't see the point in it.
This is just my opinion, please don't kill me.

reviewText:
A lot of other people have said it, and I'm just gonna add to the chorus.  Time between iterations is too damn high.  I get that the game wants to be atmospheric, but when you die, (and you will die often), it takes a long time to get back into the action.

The game actually kind of reminds me of football in that way.  Lots of screen time, almost no play.

When you die, the camera watches your corpse get mangled for about five seconds.  Then, it fades to black for five seconds.  Then when it loads, you have to wait five seconds for it to let you move.  Then you have to walk all the way back to whatever boss you were on, which can take five seconds, if you were on the first boss, to something more like a minute for later ones.  Oh, and dodge rolling into stairs or walls stuns you for a long time.  That part I kinda get; it teaches you not to do it in level.  But it's still kinda frustrating that there's no easy way back.  All those little loading times add up, and I was spending more time between fights than actually in them.

Just... look; all game devs, ever: look at Super Meat Boy.  See how it takes less than a second to get back into the fun part of the game?  Let us do that.  Don't bog us down with the frustrating or empty bits.  This is the same problem with prequels to movies (if the movie was the most interesting part in the character's life, why would we want to see something less interesting?)  If the gameplay is the fun part, why would we want to have to play the not-fun part over and over?

reviewText: I know my play time is only 10 minutes. I was pretty sure that I would get a refund but wanted to try the game out if my huntch was right. Titan Souls is like an 8bit version of the PS2 hit Shadow of Colossus in which you are tasked to kill huge colossi' to advance in the story with very little gamplay besides that. You dodge the atttacks of the titans, trying to find the weakness and then the spot to deliver the arrow there. In 10 minutes I managed to kill 2 of these titans and tried the third one once. It's a fun idea but overall quite bland in my opinion.

reviewText:
Titan Souls puts you in the shoes of a child protagonist who is armed only with a bow holding a single arrow. You roam through the remnants of an ancient civilization and the lairs of gargantuan creatures, each of which you are required to kill. Why you have chosen to visit these lands and why these Titans need to be killed is never explained. While this may be seen as a weakness the lack of explanation has a beneficial effect on the atmosphere of the lands you roam through.

Titan Souls is similar to Dark Souls in the sense that through deaths you will start to learn the boss pasterns and master the fights. There is one main difference, if you hit the Titan once with your arrow on the vulnerable spot it will die instantly. In similar fashion, you will die instantly if you get hit once by the Titan. To aid you in your task is a simple yet precise set of controls. As you only have a single arrow in your possession you need to make your shots count. Charging up the bow will make it fly faster and further. Once you have taken your shot you can run or dodge your way towards to arrow to pick it up or use your power to pull it back towards you (requires you to stand absolutely still though). This can get very hectic as the Titan will not sit around while you recover your arrow.

In the best moments, you will barely dodge your way past the Titans hands slamming on the ground, shooting your arrow at a perfect angle at the wall and using your power to draw the arrow back right into the Titans' back to finish it off. In the worst case scenario, you will get frustrated over a great number of deaths only to have a random shot kill the Titan and feel no sense of accomplishment at all. Futhermore, while most boss fights are original the level of difficulty can be both very high or very low for certain fights which makes for an uneven progression through the game.

Final score 9/10
+Thrilling and challenging fights
+Simple and precise controls
+Pixel art

-Can be frustrating; death comes quickly and often.
-Sense of accomplishment can be diminished by finishing a fight through luck and not skill.
-Spikes and dips in difficulty.
-Somewhat short

reviewText: Taking a cue from Shadow of the Collosus this is a game where you, armed with only a bow with a single arrow and the ability to roll and call back your shot after firing it, must kill the Titans. You die in one hit, but fortunately so do the Titans and the battles quickly become a dispute to see who will land the first(and last) blow. Expect to die a lot of times, but the game isn't ballbusting difficut(at least in it's normal mode).\n\nDespite all that, the game is very short, with one playthrough lasting around two hours. Buy at a discounted price or if you're interested in replaying it's alternate modes(Hard Mode, One Life Mode and No Rolling mode),

reviewText: Difficult but good.  Everything is a one-hit kill.  This include the character and the bosses (although many of them are shielded).  You have only one weapon, a bow that you can charge up and a single arrow that you can pull back to you.  You have only one other move, a dodge-roll that can transition into a slightly-faster-than-usual run.\n\nThe concept is good, the game is simple and difficult like a classic Nintendo game, and the controls are fairly tight.  It could do with a little more story/motivation/reward for playing the game and playing it well, but it suffices pretty nicely even without that.

reviewText:
I've read a lot of the negative reviews and I can see what people are getting at,it's not the most polished of experiences and truth be told after 4 hours (1 of those spent on a boss with laser eyes and two stupid fists I hate so god damn much that I just want to rarrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrGFDHDKSHSKKSHSKSNSK................I don't have any desire to continue or replay it or god forbid speed run it.

But that said, I enjoyed the experience a lot, it's an atmospheric nicely realised world with the type oof exploration I enjoy. reviewText:
Finished 100% of the game in normal difficulty. Still haven't replayed it through it's various modes though. Here are some thoughts on it:

Pros:
- Great atmosphere: The soundtrack, retro landscapes and bosses all blend in togerther very nicely.
- Challenging: The painful repetitive deaths force the player to be mindful and evaulate each boss encounter.
- Replayability: The unlockable modes add a lot of replayability for those inclined to challenge themselves further.

Cons:
- Too simple: Simplicity is good but in moderation. The only thing the player has to think about is boss strategy. There is no added layer of complexity outside of it. For example, the fire arrow mechanic used to access Onyxia's lair is a good idea but it isn't developed further. I could see the addition of other kinds of arrows, bows or even boots while maintaining the simple 1-hit-kill-or-die gameplay. By this, I do not mean adding an RPG-like inventory system but just the implementation of other small ideas which would make the game require more thought outside of the boss battles.
- Small sense of achievement: The only reward a player gets throughout the game is the pleasure of overcoming the battles. Some kind of growth, character progression or cummulative reward system could help here. The steam achievement system helps to make up for it though.

I'd give the game an overall 8/10.

reviewText:
4/5 Good

Titan Souls is effectively a challenge mode -- its content consists largely of moving between quasi-puzzle boss fights. This and its general aesthetic are highly similar to the PS2 cult hit Shadow of the Colossus.

However, unlike SotC, Titan Souls lacks any sort of content or progression beyond these boss fights -- both your character and all bosses (except one) die in one single hit, and your only weapon remains a magic bow with a single, returning arrow. Your only movement technique is rolling.

The challenge of the game is that only one specific spot on each boss is vulnerable to attack and only at certain times, and you have to figure out how to expose it. A single hit to that spot with your arrow -- including on the return -- will defeat the boss immediately (except one.)

Pros:
- Widely varied bosses
- Not every Titan is required to reach the last boss"
date:
only the EX last boss
- Game becomes gradually more frantic and difficult but not completely unfairly
- Magic arrow returns on command and is deadly in transit; adds meta to some boss fights
- Sectionalized content allows for both long or short play sessions
- You defeat one boss by shooting him in the butt
- Difficulty modes

Cons:
- Keyboard controls ARE NOT WASD + MOUSE
recommended:
so you're limited to shooting in 8 directions without a controller
- Very short (my first run took a mere 4 hours 17 minutes)
- Little to no content beyond boss fights and difficulty settings
- Walking to bosses is a chore
hoursPlayed:
especially between deaths
- Certain cinematics are a bit lengthy
- EX final boss is stupid and highly annoying; normal final boss is much cooler



I would do the following to improve this game:

- Allow use of WASD + Mouse for finer aiming (go ahead and fight Knight / Soul / Truth with only 8-direction aiming
voteText:
see how well it goes...)

- Allow players the option of either respawning at the boss room entrance or back at their last checkpoint

- Allow players to teleport from one discovered checkpoint to another

- Add a horse
helpfulPercent: chocobo ripoff
votesHelpful: or other much faster transport that only works outside of boss rooms (animal will visually shy away from boss rooms it could fit into)\n\n- Add optional puzzle rooms or hidden non-Titan bosses that add context clues to piece the story together
votesTotal:
none of which are required to access Truth

- Add inconsequential wildlife such as birds or squirrels

- Allow skipping of cutscenes or certain boss intros (--> Truth)"

reviewText:
Titan Souls is definitely an indie game, as most people use the term nowadays. It's akin to Cave Story in that they're both good examples of short but otherwise worthwhile experiences. Allow me to explain step by step.

Let's start with the Gameplay. We'll break it down between controls and mechanics.

As far as controls go, this game is very simple. You move your character with the arrow keys or control stick, you can shoot your solitary arrow if you have it stocked or call it back after shooting with the same button. While aiming to shoot, the arrow keys/control stick become your method of aiming instead of moving. Along with movement and arrow play, you also get a dodge button that can be held to make your character run. I highly recommend using a gamepad, some bosses are near-to-outright impossible with only 8 directions to move and shoot in.

In contrast to the simple controls, the gameplay mechanics are more in depth than one would expect. The entire game can be boiled down to a glorified boss rush. Every titan encounter is in the typical boss room" structure
date: whereas upon finding the titan in its room and engaging in it only victory or death will allow you to leave. Every boss has a weak point
recommended: but is otherwise invincible unless you hit this one spot with your own arrow. This makes each boss feel more like a battle of wits rather than strength
hoursPlayed: where solving the question of 'what' the weak point is and 'how' to hit it is as important as not being hit yourself. Learning a titan's pattern through trial and error and finding the perfect moment to attack is what this game's combat is at its core. It’s best not to get too worked up as death will happen in this game
voteText: again and again and again.\n\nOutside of battles with the various titans of this world
helpfulPercent: the player is left to explore an unexplained and quite desolate world in search of the aforementioned titans. There are little rewards for exploration if you were looking for more than another titan to fight
votesHelpful: and none if finding vague hints of the lore doesn't interest you. There are no mobs to find
votesTotal:
and no enemies to deal with and level up against. This is a world of titans and decisive actions.

Now let's talk about Narration. This topic covers story as well as the level of engagement the game is capable of putting you into.

As far as the story goes

column20: without actually putting much story to find though.\n\nDespite having such a paper thin plot

Such an in-depth game of solving the boss' puzzle coupled with the sense of true satisfaction every time I figure it out and earn victory coaxed me into taking the next step and finding the next boss to fight. In some cases

Though it isn't 'anime with 3D CGI' levels of cringe worthy obviousness

reviewText:
Dodgy keyboard control aside - I decided to fork out the additional cash for a gamepad so I could enjoy this title the way the developers intended - this game is a testament to what a bossrush/bossfight game can be.

Hear me out -

This game is far from perfect
I walked into a snowball and got stuck - permanently. I had to quit the game and start it up again because there is no option to just respawn at the last checkpoint.

I played the first 4 bosses on keyboard, and I got so frustrated with the controls that I decided the 10 pounds for a gamepad was worth it, just to ease my frustration. DO NOT I repeat DO NOT play this game without a gamepad. You will rip your hair out.

A few graphical issues and weird hitboxes made the game less fun at times, whether they were intended or not is not my concern, I got past them.
BUT
What this game did right
Gorgeous pixel art style, tastefully done to the point that you aren't thrown out of immersion. If you liked the art style of Shadow of the Colossus (I know that everybody makes this comparison but it is a valid one), imagine that but in stunning pixely goodness.

Brilliantly composed sountrack, if you don't play the game at least take the time to listen to the OST. Trust me.

The fights are, in theory, simple. There is nothing difficult about this game IN THEORY. Enemies have a weak point. You have an arrow. Your entire body is your weak point. Hit their weak point before they hit you.

Simple, right? But then you missed the first shot and there are 10 icicles dropping at your face and oh f*** your arrow is over there but you have to stand still to pull it to you a-

Ded.

You'll spend a life or two just sussing out the boss, finding its weak point, learning how it moves and attacks. Then you'll know EXACTLY how to beat him; God it's gonna be so easy this time DAMNIT I forgot about that other thing he does.

Ded.

There is a, not immediately apparent, underlying story to this game that (as much as I haven't finished the content yet) looks intriguing, made up, so far, of wall murals and  a secret boss who lets himself be killed because he can see the pain in your soul, stating do what you need" as you draw your bow and fire directly into his eye. Wow.

Every boss feels unique
date: and I haven't had any feelings of a boss being "cheap"
recommended: Aside from greed amirite hahahahaha kill me  or a boss having any abilities that I felt were overpowered or "broken".\n\nThis game is hard because it is HARD. It is not hard because you get killed in one hit
hoursPlayed: that plays a part but it doesn't up the difficulty THAT much. This game has earned the reputation of being hard
voteText: because it requires you to be dextrous
helpfulPercent: have fast reactions
votesHelpful: know when to use one of the game's mechanics instead of another
votesTotal: and even at some points to avoid attacking at a particular time because it could screw you over for the rest of the fight. This game requires skill
votesFunny: not luck
commentsCount:
and certainly not just trying again and again and again until the stars align because the boss is TOO hard.
TL;DR
Hard game. Buy gamepad. Fun to play. Music good. Some glitches. Art nice. Worth buy.


Overall

reviewText:
I went in expecting the game to be challenging, and got a game that was just frustrating.
Firstly, the controls are simple, in fact too simple. Putting two functions (roll and run) on the same button makes it very difficult to survive bosses because I was constantly messing up, forgetting to keep holding down X because I just had to press it to roll. Also, why isn't running the default movement pattern? The world is too large to just stroll around in, because then you'll just get bored. Back to the controls, aiming is a b**ch since you can only use the arrow keys, which is incredibly inprecise. It'd be easier if there was real mouse support.
Secondly, the map is confusing. Bosses are not easy to find beyond the first set of 4, and there are plenty of branching paths from the spawnpoints that lead you RIGHT BACK to the spawnpoint. If these paths don't lead anywhere, why are they here? Just to give an example, there are two bosses in the forest/swamp area. To reach the one to your right, you have to take the right path, then when you get to the next area, immediately turn back around. When you get back to the spawn area, it's no longer the spawn area and it leads you to the second boss. How is that sound design? And how was I supposed to know that? The game is already challenging enough with the bosses, making it harder and take longer to reach them (because it does those bosses are sooo far off) only takes away from the game.
The bosses are difficult, and if you can overlook controls and map and want a challenge then this is for you. If you don't like what I've written, don't buy the game.
voteText: 11 of 25 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Beautiful, challenging, and mysterious.

Take a deep breath, fire your singular arrow, and awake the slumbering beast.

Titan Souls has no intention of grasping your sweaty palm.

Observation is key to discovering the weaknesses of the imaginative and vastly varied Titans. Avoid their attacks and your opportunity will reveal itself, though how and when to exploit it often remains unclear. Fortunately, you have infinite lives to try different tactics, because you will quickly burn through many of them. As unforgiving as this process is, I've rarely felt truly frustrated - I've simply not understood what needed to be done, or failed to execute it within the narrow window. You face a short walk back to the battle arena after defeat. I used this time to reflect on why I'd failed and how I could change my approach to succeed. Still, over time these treks become marathons, and an option to cut straight to the action would have avoided this. Controls are tight and responsive, provided you heed the strong recommendation of a game pad. Seriously, keyboard controls are futile here.

The world is pretty and detailed, yet feels slightly hollow - its a lonely journey. This was most likely to convey the isolation of your vulnerable protagonist, and this works, but some rewarding exploration would have created a more vibrant world, rather than just a hub leading to battles.

The score is glorious. Wistful, ethereal music accompanies the main world, ominously fading to silence once you enter a dungeon, replaced with pounding tribal beats and darting strings once battle initiates.

When that perfectly aimed arrow connects and the giant is slain, it is satisfaction and disbelief combined. Only one task remains - retrieve your lone weapon.

An immensely rewarding game, it deserves to be valued on its own merit, not stand in the Shadow" of any other."

reviewText:
Despite my playtime on it as of writing this review, I feel I can say a decent amount about how FREAKING AWESOME this game is! I'm playing Bloodborne right now so I knew going into this game was going to require a lot of reaction skill, and I ended up clearing the first 4 bosses no sweat (The Ice Cube was a b*tch until I learned the secret to the room!), and I'm sure by saying that karma is going to come back and absolutely obliterate me :D

Getting real, I found a ton of things I love already: the soundtrack is gorgeous! It's a unique style I haven't heard in many games, but the boss music and the exploring music fits in perfectly (especially when you die the first time to the boss before the elevator!)

The pixel graphics I was surprised by. I know you can make art with pixels and make it look really good, but in Titan Souls the artwork done is fantastic! They really put their hearts into making this game look as good as it plays.

Gameplay is very simple, with only, like, three buttons needed, I would still take their advice on using a gamepad for this. You get used to it very quick and I started using the gamepad right away when I booted up, and it's been a smooth ride (except for one point where my arrow was stuck in it's draw phase and wouldn't get out of it until I died. Possible bug? Or perhaps my controller was being stupid :P)

If you were lazy and decided to skip to the final verdict of this insanely long review, just buy it. You won't have any doubts putting this game in your library, especially with it being on sale atm. Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy of this, even if it's just for the soundtrack and artwork.

Also, it should probably be mentioned this game can make you laugh like hell! It's easy to screw up hardcore and die in the most hilarious of ways!

BUY IT.

reviewText:
I actually found this pretty fantastic- maybe not for the price? I got this on discount, and its incredibly hard. Its essentially a well made pixel game where you fight 4 bosses. I've not hit the last boss but its incredibly challenging and makes you, most of all think.

Your own weapons consist of just a arrow bow set, but the arrow returns with your call. Juggling this, that makes you stand still, becomes a challenge. Still, I very much do recommend it as a enthralling time killer. It makes you think yet sort of not? And I'm a -very- picky gamer.

In terms of the think yet not idea, you have to both use an active mind and instinct then reflect afterwards to see what tactic works. If you expect winning to fall in your lap, just don't buy it. Its something you have to work for. Half the time I was playing I was running in circles watching how the bosses move.

Edit: I just looked at more content and I'm pretty sure there is a lot more content after the 4th boss that I didn't notice in a quick glance of the page. So for me to say this in 3 bosses in says something XD

reviewText: Many of the reviews I have seen are straight to the point of it being 'short' and in regards to finishing it, I have to agree. But with the quite short time I had with this game, the finishing time didn't matter, it's the experience that matters. Seeing the boss for the first time and wondering what made it trigger, getting instantly squished, impaled, melted or vaporised (respectively), staying back to discover the attack pattern of the boss (while being assaulted with vines, fists, icicles, magical arrows of death etc,)  getting enough courage to take shots between attacks and finally taking it down. All of this was what makes this game great. Regarded, I still havent versed the majority of the bosses, but the ones I did fight were quite a challenge with the final fight making me physically gasp and then punch my fist in the air with joy when I finally took it down. I plan to go back to this game in the future.\n9/10

reviewText:
This game.... i cannot recommend it more, it has a simplistic feel, and can be quite frustrating with how easy it is to die, yet its hard to stop playing....

there are 3 major things feel make this game great
1: This is a skill based game, you have to earn your win, luck helps, but skill wins
2: The artwork in this game is astounding, its simple and it feels right
3: The soundtrack fits the feel of the game like a glove

and you can expect, when reviews are formatted like this, there are always downsides
so there are 2 flaws that i have found
1: The game is short, knowing nothing about the game, mechanics, or bosses, i finished all 19 bosses on normal mode in just over 4 hours
2: There needs to be a way to find the lore in the game, it feels like it has a great story, but i have yet to find a way to explore it

This game deserves a go, it might be a bit overpriced at 15-20 bucks for its playtime (on the normal mode), but if you are interested in a game that will make you want to punch your monitor in fury, and feel a rush of fulfillment when you climb the hurdle that was in your way, this game is for you

Sound: 10/10
Art: 10/10
Challenge: 8/10 (on normal)
Value: 5/10

I am looking forward to challenging the harder modes

reviewText: (Total change of my reveiw)\nYou may see a lot of people who have not found this reveiw helpful, pay no mind to them, they are probablly a few people who ragequit this game (I don't blame them) and are now so salty they go through the positive reveiw section downvoting every one without a second thought.  Now, I will say this game is rather light on content, but don't let that fool you into thinking this is a short game.  Beating it on the normal difficulty mode may take up to a few hours, but it's more to get you acquainted with the bosses you'll be dieing to in Hard mode.  See, this game is fashioned to be part Shadow of the Colossus, part Dark Souls, and (mostly) 2d.  So this means that hard mode is going to grind your face into the ground.  You can mix that in with Iron mode (One life) and prepare to rage harder than you ever have before in your life.  The soundtrack's appealing, and the gameplay is quite smooth.  I'd give this an 8/10 for the lack of content, but what IS there is polished and well made.  So all of you people who can't get past The Keeper of the First Gate, just slow down, and take a few moments to chill out before you go at it again.

reviewText:
This review is coming from a standpoint having beaten every boss on both normal and hard mode.

This isn't a game where I can definitively say buy or don't buy. And instead of listing the typical pros and cons list, let me give you reasons to pick this up and reasons not to.


Reasons to buy:
The difficulty. This game is incredibly challenging while remaining enjoyable. While some may disagree, this game is unforgiving but not unfair. On my first run of the game, I managed to beat it in about three hours. In the process, I killed 18 Titans and died almost 200 times. Not once did I feel like the game was too difficult. Don't get me wrong, this game is hard. But still very enjoyable. And you have no idea the type of satisfaction you get when one boss has been handing you your ♥♥♥ for the past half hour and you finally manage to beat him.
The gameplay. Everything from the world to each individual boss fight felt unique and stylized. The game has character and that's something noteworthy. However, once you learn a Titan's attack patterns and weakness, most of them can be killed in ten seconds or less. You definitely won't be doing that on your first run though.
The soundtrack. God, the soundtrack is beautiful. It's the only thing I listen to on my iPod anymore. Worth the extra $5.
The artsyle. You can take a look at the screenshots and see for yourself. I can't get enough of it.
The controls. With a gamepad, this handles masterfully and smoothly.
Reasons not to buy:
The price. Once I beat the game once through on normal and again on hard, I found myself sitting at about 8 hours of playtime. Is that enough for $15 USD or your regional equivalent? Maybe. For me, yes. Definitely. I'm still getting massive enjoyment out of trying to speedrun hard mode.
The story. There isn't one. Except for the Maker's dialogue, but even then that hardly counts.
The controls. Without a gamepad, this game is god awful. Do not buy this unless you have a working 360 or PS4 controller. Spare yourself.
The mechanics. There is little progression in this game other than beat bosses to unlock more bosses. For people seeking that compelling RPG game with skill trees and talents, look elsewhere.


This game is geared towards a very specific type of person. I happen to be that type and I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. However, if you aren't that type, you'd be better off buying something else.

It's a shame that one of the devs is a child when it comes to criticism. I feel like some people are letting that poison their thoughts of the game, which is fair enough.


TL;DR: This game might be for you, it might not be. Wow, whodathunkit.
voteText: 11 of 26 people (42%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't like Titan Souls personally, but I still recommend it.

The sound and art design in this game are wonderful, it has tight controls and is incredibly atmospheric with its minimalist design.

I've beaten the game giving each boss about a dozen tries, checking if I understood what I was doing wrong, if yes then keep trying, if no then watch a video to see what I'm not understanding. That is the crux of my own dislike of the game, a lot of bosses kill me too quickly to actually glean useful information from them. Experimenting with a different setup is possible, but sometimes you die immediately during an optimal setup and dismiss it only to realize you had it right the 4th time. The boss designs themselves are strong and when you finally figure out how to kill a boss quickly it's satisfying, the road there isn't enjoyable for myself though.

This isn't a slight on the design, there is extreme clarity in the choices they made in this game and it has a solid voice. I recommend it to other people who have patience and appreciate a well crafted experience.

reviewText:
As many others have said, this feels more like a proof-of-concept than a game. Sounds harsh, and feels harsh, because the game genuinely plays extremely well, but there's not much to it.

I haven't played much, and haven't gotten very far, so I can't claim that I know the story. From what I gather, you're a dude with a single arrow (which is admittedly a very strong arrow) tasked with taking down Titans and gathering their Souls, which I don't feel the title inferred well enough. Basically, you line up a shot, take it, and then can recall your arrow via some kind of psychic link. You must battle several bosses, and that's pretty much it. Each of the bosses has their own quirks, weaknesses, strengths, attacks, and designs, and it's always a nice 'daunting' feeling when you walk into a new boss room for the first time.

It's a good game, for sure. The design and art is absolutely fantastic, with a hint of retro-flair to it. Each boss has been wonderfully and maticulously crafted, and the work shows for sure. Titan Souls does a very good job of drawing you into its strange world, and the bosses feel as intimidating as their size would have you believe. It's challenging from the first boss onward, and only gets rougher from there. I've found that it's one of those games where you can switch off with your friends without anyone getting too bored from watching. Pretty damn good, best for fans of LoZ or Colossus, but I probably wouldn't buy it full price.

reviewText:
Kind of boring.  The only thing to do is walk around and fight the bosses.  Some bosses are super easy, some are very difficult and require almost pixel perfect timing.  You die in one hit, bosses die in one hit.

Controls are terrible.  Having run and roll on the same button (actually, on an XBOX controller you get three run/roll buttons and three shoot buttons) is stupid and/or lazy.  Graphics are not impressive.  Sound effects are not impressive.  Music is meh.

Biggest issue is a game with one shot kill mechanics and lots of trial and error to fight the bosses is the huge delay between attempts.  A game like IWBTG, or something like Castle in the Darkness, you die, push button, respawn and go back to playing.  This game, you die, there's a few seconds of fade out, then a fade in, then watching youreself get up from the spawn, and then walking back to the boss room to try again.

When you finally win a fight, you aren't even happy because it means you get to go walk for five minutes around a big empty world to find the next boss.  This game is somehow a more boring Shadow of the Colossus, with less story and less epic boss fights.  If you have trouble sleeping at night, this may be a game for you.

reviewText:
Bought this after hearing some praise for its interesting style and gameplay.
All in all, it really is fun, but *sometimes* its just laughably easy.

I finished the base game (which is just beating all of the titans up to the end credit sequence. I'm sure there are more bosses to beat as there are a few titans I wasn't able to find, but know exist from the glowing dots scattered throughout various checkpoints.)

Just from that, I finished in about 2 hours in 180 deaths.

For a game that seemed to emphasize challenge with its 1-shot, 1-kill rule for both you and the boss, I expected it take longer to beat. To be fair, there were several bosses that gave me a hard time (the narrow timing on the arrow knight was particularly frustrating), but, honestly, most bosses go down within a few tries once you've seen the gimmick. The worst of this was the rolling eye encased in rock boss. Didn't even get to see his attack pattern - just waited in the bottom left corner and caught him in the eye after the initial dodge. A lot of fights go like that, and, while most fights felt satisfying, some felt like I just stomped the boss into the dirt and walked out the door laughing at the absurdity of it.

Fun, but a bit overrated. Seems to want to capture the feeling of pulling off a clutch, near death kill at the last second, but extends this to every fight and falls a bit short.

I'd still recommend it, but maybe wait for a sale.

reviewText:
This game is like Shadow of the Colossus meets Dark Souls meets Legend of Zelda. I'm only part way through at this point, but it is absolutely fantastic so far.

Some people are complaining about it being repetetive on the fights? I don't know wtf they're talking about. Every boss is unique. Sure, they all have a weakpoint you have to hit, but the method of hitting it is very different for each boss. Learning their attack patterns (and trying to stay alive long enough TO learn them) makes each fight challenging and intense.

Another complaint I saw was the lack of story. Why do you need a giant narration or deep story for $15? Honestly, this has more story than some $60 games I've played... Finding the secrets and reading the boss names adds alot of flavor to the game.

MY only complaint is that you can't change the keyboard controls. From watching videos, I kinda thought that shooting the arrow would be done with the mouse, but the videos were done with a controller. With the keyboard, you use the arrow keys and X and C, so aiming is only 8-directional and makes things quite a bit harder. But it's STILL fun with that limitation. Maybe even more fun if you like that kind of challenge.

I honestly hope that there is either more added to the game over time or a sequel is made. I highly recommend this one.

reviewText:
simple. fun. challenging. nice soundtrack and visuals. solid gameplay.

Some people are complaining about the time it takes it walk from the save pont to the boss. see for yourself, if you played the demo, the time it takes to get to any boss is about the same as that as it is in the demo. It never bothered me so much that I thought it ruined the games experience.

Others are complaining about there being bad suppport for keyboard controls, I played on a gamepad and thought the controls were very fluid, the game strongly recommends gamepads, mainly xbox or playstation, It might not work with another brand of gamepad.

From someone who has played the full game and unlocked all but the no death achievements, 15 dollars is a fair price. if you are someone who always waits for sales, it is very likely this will go on sale in the summer for 8-10 dollars. totally worth it.

the game just feels like a well-oiled machine. when i wasn't fighting one of the nineteen bosses I was walking through some happy pixel art scenery and listening to a great soundtrack with great ambient outside noises. i would love to see something alongthe lines of a titan souls 2.

8/10 a refreshing and satisfying indie single player experience
